Master and OOW: Use traditional position fixing and navigational techniques to cross-check navigational information.
CAUTION
Note
Whichever of the above methods is used by the OOW to verify the ship’s position, it is necessary to mark the verification in the ENC.

sections.name: 14.1.1 Global Navigational Satellite Systems (GNSS)
sections.content: GNSS, and more specifically GPS, are particularly effective when integrated with ECDIS. These systems give real-time global coverage and are highly reliable.

sections.name: 14.1.2 Celestial Observations
sections.content: Celestial navigation remains a valid means of positioning and an excellent back-up to GNSS and compass checking, particularly when offshore.

sections.name: 14.1.3 Dead Reckoning (DR) and Estimated Position (EP)
sections.content: Dead reckoning (DR) is predicting where you will be, based upon speed and course. An ‘estimated position’ (EP) refines that prediction further by applying set and drift. Estimating where you must be at what time is very useful for aiding situational awareness and giving advanced warning of any anomalies in other means of positioning.

sections.name: 14.1.4 Radar Image Overlay (RIO)
sections.content:
RIO is a quick and effective way to monitor the ship’s position relative to the planned route in coastal and pilotage waters. RIO is important when cross-checking GNSS positions, because any misalignment between the radar image on the ECDIS and the charted coastline on ECDIS can give an early indication of position accuracy.
Note
Guidelines for Radar Image Overlay are provided in Appendix 7.

sections.name: 14.1.5 Parallel Indexing (PI)
sections.content:
PI is a useful method of monitoring cross track tendency in both poor and good visibility. The principle of this method is that, in order to maintain and follow a particular course, a line is drawn from a fixed reference point, parallel to ship’s course, with a known and fixed perpendicular distance. Any increase or decrease of the perpendicular distance between the line drawn parallel to ship’s course and ship’s current position will indicate cross track deviation from the initial planned course and thus an indication that the ship is falling out of the planned track and may come close to a navigational hazard.
The reference point from which the bearing line parallel to course line is drawn must be for example a fixed buoy, light house, headland, jetty, fixed platform or fixed radar conspicuous object. Thus, the line drawn parallel to the course to steer from a fixed object is always at a fixed distance from it.
Parallel indexing from floating objects cannot be accepted unless they have been first checked for a position. A floating object will not give an accurate position.
CAUTION
The parallel index may also be used to monitor other events, e.g., a wheel over position. In this case the range and bearing of the reference point at the wheel over point and the new track is marked on the passage plan.
Inconspicuously mark the planned PI on the ENCs at the planning stage, for various legs of the passage, where the distance from fixed reference points is not more than 12 nm.

sections.name: 14.1.6 Visual / Radar Observation
sections.content:
There are 3 different methods to confirm the GNSS position within coastal or confined waters by fixing observed position on ECDIS:
• Visual or radar position fix with the use of EBL and VRM features. It is the simplest way to cross-check GNSS position, while navigating with ECDIS. Obtain visual or radar bearing and radar distance from a distinguished mark and transfer them to ECDIS by EBL and VRM.
• Visual or radar position fix with use of cross bearings function. This method requires more time as the ship’s position is determined with the use of at least two lines of position. Obtain at least two visual or radar bearing from a distinguished mark and transfer them to ECDIS by the EBL function.
• Visual or radar position fix with use of LOP function. This is a more sophisticated method of manual position fixing on ECDIS, valuable when GNSS failure occurs. It enables to set a reference point used for DR. Reference point function causes own ship position to shift and, therefore, this method is not recommended to be used while navigating with properly functioning GNSS receiver.
• Note
DO NOT use Buoys alone for position verification.

sections.name: 14.1.7 Depth Comparison using the Echo Sounder
sections.content: This is a complementary tool to confirm when you come across anticipated depth areas, but can rarely give an independent position. The ship can follow a depth contour as a simple form of indexing.

sections.name: 14.2 Frequency of Position Verification
sections.content:
The position of the ship is always available to the Master and the OOW. Therefore:
OOW: NEVER minimize your input to the bridge team, by solely undertaking the responsibility to apply position fixing to the ECDIS at very frequent intervals.
The following position verification intervals are recommended:
Position Verification Intervals
Navigation Area
Intervals
Open Waters
Once every watch
Coastal Waters
At least hourly
Confined / Pilotage Waters
At least every 30 mins.

sections.name: 14.3 ECDIS Screenshot
sections.content:
Saving a “screenshot” on the ECDIS hard drive is an efficient and easy way of recording bridge team actions. It can serve as proof for GNSS position cross-checking utilizing observed position fixing, use of RADAR overlay when in coastal and confined waters, use of proper safety contour setting, etc. Furthermore, it can be used as a way of building a history of previously made trips, which could be checked again when necessary.
The following ECDIS screenshot intervals are recommended:
ECDIS Screenshot Intervals
Navigation Area
Intervals
Open Waters
At least hourly
Coastal Waters
At least every 30 mins
Confined / Pilotage Waters
At least every 15 mins.
Navigation Officer:
• Retain the “screenshots” on ECDIS hard drive for 3 months.
• Create a backup copy of ECDIS screenshots on a USB memory device every 3 months (01st January, 01st April, 01st July and 01st October).
• Mark the USB memory device as follows: “ECDIS Screenshots 01 (or 2, or 3, or 4) / yyyy”. Retain the USB memory device under your custody for 3 years.

sections.name: 15 ECDIS Passage Planning
sections.content:
The passage planning includes appraisal, detailed planning of the whole voyage from berth to berth, including the areas where a pilot is needed, execution of the plan and monitoring of ship’s progress during the implementation of the plan.
15.1 Route Appraisal
The appraisal must assess the hazards associated with the passage and determine whether or not the intended passage is achievable. Although the passage plan will be constructed, refined and later activated on ECDIS for the execution and monitoring stages, the appraisal is a high-level overview. It must include supporting information such as UKC, draft, tidal streams, environmental considerations and ETAs. Such information must be documented along with supporting extracts from relevant publications.
Master:
• Assign the designated Navigation Officer to determine the feasibility of the voyage.
• Make the final decision on whether a Port or voyage is unsuitable or unsafe.
Master: NEVER proceed on voyage or enter a Port without necessary charts and publications for the voyage.
CAUTION
Navigation Officer:
• Brief the Master if it appears at an early stage that the port, berth or voyage may not be suitable for the ship.
• Take into consideration all available information and use approved publications, as per Flag requirements and industry best practices on the appraisal process.
• Note
Follow the passage plan appraisal checklist N 002 during the appraisal process, to verify that all information pertinent to the passage had been considered.
15.1.1 Destination
Master / Navigation Officer: Consider the following:
• Suitability of the ship, taking into account the following:
  o Ship
     Certification appropriate for the intendent voyage (e.g., ship sanitation)
     Draft, including any reduction to UKC, other clearances (e.g., air draft)
     Load line restrictions and requirements (i.e., compliance with applicable zones and seasonal conditions of the ICLL)
     Equipment (i.e., mooring and anchoring equipment)
     Maneuvering characteristics
     Operational limitations and stability.
  o Crew
     Certification
     Work and rest hours
     Proper manning.
  o Cargo and Bunkers
     Special characteristics (e.g., hazardous cargo)
     Distribution, stowage and securing onboard
     Approval for intended cargo operations.
     Bunkers consumption and safety margin
  o Ports and berths
     Compliance with Port State regulations and industry best practices (e.g., funnel emissions, ballast water treatment)
     ISPS requirements
     Inward and outward clearance process
     Restrictions and limitations
  o Other
     Reporting/Charterer requirements
     Medical/quarantine requirements
     Additional security considerations (e.g., piracy areas, stowaways)
     Pilotage considerations
     Weather concerns (e.g., typhoons, ice etc.).
• Calculate distance by using the ECDIS passage planning software or the ECDIS VRM. The distance can be verified by any alternative mean such as tabulated distance tables (see Ocean Passages for the World). The initial distance calculated will be an approximate distance; refine while the passage plan is developed.
• Duration can be calculated using the distances established and the average safe speed. With this information it is applicable:
  o To determine whether the ship can achieve any required ETA (if specified by the company and/or the charterer)
  o To determine the ETA at specific points along the route at varying speeds. This allows consideration of UKC clearance and bridge team manning for areas requiring special attention.
Note
The requirement for a safe speed must be considered for all legs of the voyage and entered in the ECDIS during the planning stage when the overall ETA/planned speeds are confirmed.
15.1.2 Meteorology
The meteorological factors that may affect the passage need to be determined.
Navigation Officer: Estimate the likely conditions of the intendent passage by gathering:
• Climatological information by consulting routeing/pilot charts and sailing directions.
• Forecast information by consulting weather charts.
• Current data by consulting routeing/pilot charts and other sources. Consider the surface currents, as they can have a significant effect on the passage overall time.
• Tidal data, including heights of tide and tidal streams by consulting the ECDIS and routeing charts/tidal stream atlases.
Note
The Company may, in specific cases, arrange an access to third party weather routeing services delivered via email or via an online portal.
15.1.3 Datums
ENC position data is referenced to horizontal datum, while depth and height data are referenced to a vertical datum and a sounding datum.
15.1.3.1 Horizontal Datum
All ENCs use the WGS84 horizontal datum, which allows the seamless coverage of the entire world and ensures interoperability with existing GNSS equipment onboard (see Paragraph 11.3). Navigation Officer: Be aware that possible sources of errors of position for charted features may include datum discrepancies, survey errors, geographical changes and ENC production errors. Check that the horizontal datum in use for navigation is WGS84.
15.1.3.2 UKC Calculation and Datum
Navigation Officer:
• Calculate the UKC by adding the height of tide (HoT) to the sounding datum.
• Use the charted depth directly from ECDIS display, as each charted depth sounding is referenced to the ENC sounding datum.
15.1.3.3 Vertical Clearance, Air Draft and Vertical Datum
The vertical and sounding datum are not standardized. Elevations and soundings will equate to those used on the equivalent paper chart and source data (see Paragraph 13)
Navigation Officer:
• Determine the difference between the sounding datum and the vertical datum when calculating the vertical clearance.
• Use the pick report function to check the datum information and ensure that safe clearance calculations use the correct vertical datum.
15.1.4 ENC Management and Installation
Obtain adequate ENCs for the entire passage in sufficient time to allow detailed planning and briefing of the passage to be carried out (see Paragraph 12).
Note
A list of ENCs needed for the intended voyage must be part of the appraisal.
Navigation Officer:
• Ensure that the ECDIS has all ENC cells of an appropriate scale installed for the planning stage (including a safety allowance of 50 nm on either side of the planned track for deviation/contingency).
• The license of all ENCs planned to be used for the intended voyage must be valid for the entire voyage period.
• Obtain licenses for and use the largest scale of ENCs available for all stages of each passage.
CAUTION
• Identify any ENCs missing from the ship’s folio and obtain them at the earliest opportunity from the authorized ENC distributor.
• Proceed with a Risk Assessment if the intendent route could not be fully covered by the ENCs and inform the Office.
15.1.5 ENC Updates
ECDIS maintains a list of updates applied and the date of application.
Navigation Officer: Ensure that all ENCs planned to be used for the intended voyage are being kept up-to-date (see Paragraph 12).
15.1.6 Areas of Low ENC Accuracy
In ENCs, the quality of survey data is displayed across the ENC using CATZOC symbols. Understanding of these symbols is critical to interpreting the accuracy of presented survey data and establishing appropriate safe margins (see Paragraph 11).
Navigation Officer:
• Check the data quality (CATZOC) function for the entire passage plan.
• Identify the low accuracies of positions and depths.
Lower CATZOC ratings (C, D or U) indicate that a wider safety margin (including both horizontally and vertically) between the ship’s planned track and hazards or dangers must be allowed.
CAUTION
15.1.7 Other Considerations
Completing an appraisal report, a list of factors, depending on the type of the ship and the geographic area through which the passage is planned, must be evaluated.
Navigation Officer: Consider the following factors:
• Routeing:
  o Anchorage(s), No-go areas, Safe waters, Crossing traffic
  o Ballast water exchange
  o Bridge manning
  o Restricted navigational areas, Landfall targets and lights
  o Environmental factors, including ice navigation
  o Transit in proximity to navigational hazards
  o Environmental protection areas (e.g., ECAs)
  o IALA buoyage systems
  o Speed limits and restrictions
  o Pilotage requirements
  o Precautionary and Security areas
  o Territorial waters
  o Time zones and time changes
  o Traffic density, Traffic separation scheme (TSS), other routeing measures
  o VTS and ship reporting systems.
• Contingencies:
  o For emergencies/equipment failures/breakdowns
  o Potential areas to conduct drifting and/or proceed to anchorage
  o Points of non-return/abort points
  o Where there is a deterioration in the weather conditions
  o For customs/medical/quarantine reasons
  o Place of refuge
  o For operations such as gas freeing, purging, ballast water exchange.
15.1.8 Advising the Master
Once the Appraisal Report (N 002) has been completed, the detailed planning can begin.
Navigation Officer:
Advise the Master accordingly.

sections.name: 15.2 Route Planning
sections.content:
Following the appraisal of all charts, publications and other information, prepare a route plan to cover the entire passage from berth to berth, including those areas where a pilot is needed.
Note
If the destination has not been confirmed, plan a passage from berth to a point the ship is expected to sail towards.
15.2.1 Display Configuration
ENCs provide a layering of information, much of which can be turned on / off by selecting the relevant display category. To ensure that all relevant information for planning the route is shown, configure display settings prior to route construction, as per Company’s requirements.
Note
Guidelines for ECDIS Display Management are provided in Appendix 3.
Navigation Officer:
• Configure the ENC settings to enable efficient planning, initially:
  o Unload all routes/manual layers
  o Select full screen
  o Set default values for safety depth, safety contours, cross track corridor and radius turn
  o Select compilation scale to ensure that ECDIS screen displays features at the most optimum scale
  o Select “All” display mode and appropriate palette
  o Allow autoload and autoscale.
• Enter the display of auxiliary layers, provided by integration with other software or equipment:
  o AIO
  o NAVTEX
  o Route Planning Software
  o Tidal Streams / Surface Currents and Weather data.
Note
Select chart symbols (pick report) on ENCs to get additional detailed safety and navigational information.
15.2.2 Alarm Configuration
The proper alarm configuration on ECDIS is very important. During the route validation stage of the passage planning, alarms will assist the Navigation Officer in checking that there are no dangers on the route. While at sea, alarms monitoring the passage plan assist the OOW by ensuring they are aware of new or unexpected hazards or dangers.
Note
Guidelines for ECDIS Alarm Management is provided in Appendix 4.
The following alarm categories are installed on the ECDIS:
• Emergency Alarm: The highest level of an alert as it signifies immediate danger and that immediate action must be taken.
• Alarm: A high priority of alert. Condition requiring immediate attention and action, to maintain the safe navigation and operation of the ship.
• Warning: Condition requiring no immediate attention or action. Warnings are presented for precautionary reasons to bring awareness of changed conditions which are not immediately hazardous but may become so if no action is taken.
• Caution: Lowest priority of an alert. Awareness of a condition which does not warrant an alarm or warning condition, but still requires attention out of the ordinary consideration of situation or of given information.
Navigation Officer:
• Ensure that alarms are turned on - test them to ensure that they are audible.
• Set the alarm parameters as per Company’s procedures and in a manner that reduces alarm fatigue.
• Receive the Master’s agreement, regarding the alarm setting parameters, and record them to the relevant passage plan form N 001.
15.2.3 Route Creation
Navigation Officer: The objective is to use all information obtained during the appraisal, to create the safest possible route.
• Take into account any relevant ship’s routeing system.
• Ensure that sufficient sea room for safe passage of the ship throughout the voyage is available.
• Anticipate all known navigational hazards and adverse weather conditions.
Avoid, where possible, to pass from environmental sensitive areas.
CAUTION
• Adjust a planned route alphanumerically (route table) and graphically (on screen), including:
  o Adding waypoints to a route
  o Deleting waypoints from a route
  o Shifting the position of a waypoint.
• Plan one or more alternative routes in addition to the active route.
• Distinguish the active route from other routes.
• Initiate the relevant passage planning checklist N 003.
• Note
Record details of each leg in the passage planning sheet (N 001) for reference during both the current and any future voyages between the same Ports.
An arrangement of separate routes:
• Berth to pilot station
• Pilot station to pilot station
• Pilot station to berth
may be constructed and then incorporated together in the passage plan, ensuring that coverage is still berth to berth (a route must be created from berth to berth as a single route).
15.2.3.1 New Route
Navigation Officer:
• Open the route planning function and select “new route”.
• Ensure that appropriate largest scale ENCs are used.
• Ensure that the compilation scale of each ENC is used.
• Pay particular attention to where ENCs overlap.
A detailed check is essential where ENCs overlap, to ensure that no critical data has been obscured. Overlapping cells are listed in the README file (see Paragraph 7.8 ).
CAUTION
• Add waypoints:
  o Use the graphical method to construct a route. On an appropriately scaled ENC, start by adding a waypoint in the vicinity of the initial location using the cursor. When 2 waypoints are inserted, the system automatically joins them to form legs, which are rhumb lines by default. Remaining on small scale ENCs, and utilizing the knowledge received during appraisal stage, construct the route by adding all necessary waypoints till the final destination. Waypoints position need only be approximate at this stage, or
  o Use the tabular method, where the latitude and longitude of waypoints are entered manually in the route table. Leg details such as true course and distance, can be viewed in the route table or chosen display, where available, along the route itself.
• Adjust waypoints. Once the entire route is planned on small scale charts, return to the start position and conduct a more accurate planning by fine-tuning the waypoints, using appropriate large-scale charts. Place waypoints as accurately as possible.
• Note
A route planning software can be used to create and review optimum voyage routes. The software is integrated with chart management and ordering tools, overlays of NAVAREA warnings, etc.
• Consider the following when adding or adjusting waypoints:
  o Ship considerations:
     Draft in relation to available depth and width of navigable water and minimum required UKC
     Effect on ship’s draft and turning circle during course alteration:
- Planned speed
- ROT restrictions
- Effect of expected tidal stream
- Effect of expected current
- Increase in draft due to squat and heel effect.
     Optimal fuel efficiency.
  o Route considerations:
     Adequate XTC
     Alterations of speed enroute
     Avoidance of danger areas
     Contingency/emergency planning:
- Points of non-return
- Place of refuge or safe anchorage in the event of an emergency
- Shore-based emergency response arrangements and equipment.
     Depth of water, Tidal restrictions
     Limitations of night passage
     Location of course alterations
     Method and frequency of position verification
     Piracy and security
     Pilot station(s). Place a waypoint at the pilot station to ensure accurate ETA
     Protection of the environment
     Safe speed and proximity of navigational hazards
     Territorial baselines
     Use of ship’s routeing, reporting systems and VTS.
Note
By default, ECDIS will create legs as rhumb lines, but for ocean passages this can be changed to a Great Circle line.
• Plot specific details of T&P / EP NMs, navigational warnings, NAVTEX messages and local information as a manual layer and made alarmable by using the look-ahead feature to highlight the navigational hazards for the OOW. The manual layers must be displayed at least within 50 nm on either side of the planned track.
• Define the ship’s safe speed for each leg of the planned route.
• Apply any guidance or direction related to ship’s route as per the charterers orders.
• Calculate the safety depths and safety contours and set them up in line with the UKC requirements (see Paragraph 13 ).
• Set maximum acceptable cross track corridor (XTC) to each leg of a route (see Paragraph 13.9 ).
• Define the look-ahead zone (see Paragraph 13.8)
• Set parallel indexing where appropriate.
• Define abort points, critical points and emergency anchorages.
• Calculate the wheel-over positions with the applicable rate of turn.
• Plot no-go areas.
• Set ETA using the route planning tools. Be aware that if this is set incorrectly, it may affect tidal data, UKC calculations and time dependent information for the route.
• Note
When the ship regularly visits a certain Port or frequently transits an area, it is advantageous to keep the whole or part of the passage plan as it is. Unless changes are made to channels, navaids, etc. a planned passage is acceptable for future visits, taking into account the meteorological and tidal differences and that inward and outward passages may be different. Parts of the plans may have common features that can be used.
If reusing a previous passage plan, then recheck the route to confirm that it remains safe and no changes are necessary.
CAUTION
When planning, consider the following:
Open Sea
Ocean routeing charts showing ocean currents, winds, ice limits and load lines
Load line charts showing zones and seasonal periods ensure compliance with the IMO International Convention on Load Lines
Weather routeing services (if applicable)
The use of gnomonic projection charts for plotting great circle routes, as appropriate
Ocean currents and their impact on ship speed and fuel consumption
Weather conditions, including anticipated seasonal variations, e.g., heavy weather, tropical storms, ice and reduced visibility
Environmental protection measures and requirements that may extend into an ocean route
Coastal Waters
The importance of passing charted and other features at a safe distance
Advice in the sailing directions
Available depth of water and tidal information contained in tide tables/stream atlases
Availability of visual and radar fixing opportunities
Ship’s routeing and reporting measures, as well as the availability of VTS
The reliability of the ship’s propulsion and steering system
Environmental protection measures and requirements, including fuel changeover
Confined / Pilotage Waters
Recommended routes and channel information
Procedures for pilotage, including pilot boarding points and means of embarkation
Local conditions, rules and restrictions on navigation
Reporting and communications procedures
Details of the prospective berth, tugs and/or anchorages
Contingency planning for unforeseen issues
15.2.3.2 Route Supplementary Information
Inserting “anger highlights” using manual layers, ensures that the OOW is informed and reminded of potential dangers and actions to be taken at various points during the passage.
The quantity of additional information must be limited to that which is necessary to execute the route with safety and efficiency, although this will depend on industry best practices and:
• The complexity of the plan
• The environmental conditions
• The proximity of dangers
• The Master’s standing orders.
Navigation Officer: Include the following additional info, as minimum, when applicable:
• Parallel indexing, methods and frequency of position verification
• Landfall targets and lights
• Clearing lines and bearings
• Transits, heading marks and

gemini.title: Chapter 20: Cyber Security

sections.name: 20.1 Objectives
sections.content:
To:
•	Protect the Company’s business information - operation assets and any customer or
partner information within its custody by safeguarding its confidentiality, integrity and
availability.
•	Establish responsibility and accountability for cybersecurity within the Company and
the ship.
•	Encourage Management and staff to maintain an appropriate level of awareness,
knowledge and skill, allowing them to minimize the occurrence and severity of
cybersecurity incidents.
•	Ensure that the ship can continue its commercial and service activities in the event
of cybersecurity incidents.

sections.name: 20.2 Purpose
sections.content:
To:
•	Identify the personnel, data, devices, IT/OT and communication systems that pose
risks to ship operations when disrupted and define personnel roles and
responsibilities for cyber risk management.
•	Protect against cybersecurity events by implementing risk control processes,
measures and contingency planning.
•	Detect cybersecurity events promptly by developing and implementing appropriate
measurements.
•	Respond to cyber events with procedures and plans to restore the impaired systems
necessary for shipping operations or services.
•	Recover after cybersecurity events with the correct measures to backup and restore
impacted cyber systems necessary for shipping operations.
Cybersecurity Framework

sections.name: 20.3 Cyber Risk Management
sections.content:
The Company assesses the risks arising from Information Technology (IT) and Operation
Technology (OT) use and establishes appropriate safeguards against cyber incidents.
The Cybersecurity Risk Management includes:
•	Identification of the systems, assets, data, and capabilities, which, if disrupted, can
threaten the Company or ship’s operations and safety
•	Identification of the relevant threats and vulnerabilities, assessment of risk exposure,
and development of protection measures
•	Identification of the roles and responsibilities of users ashore and onboard
•	Protective measures against cyber incidents ensuring operations continuity. These
include, among others:
o	Network configuration
o	Network and system access control
o	Communication and boundary defense
o	Protection and detection software.
•	Activities and measures to prepare, respond and provide resilience against cyber
incidents. These include, among others:
o	Training and awareness
o	Software maintenance
o	Remote and local access
o	Access privileges
o	Measures for removable media use
o	Proper equipment disposal.

sections.name: 20.4.1 Top Management Leadership and Commitment
sections.content:
The Company demonstrates its commitment to cybersecurity, which extends to senior levels
of the organization through the provision of appropriate resources to develop and maintain
associated controls.
The Top Management:
•	Enforces behaviors mandated by the cybersecurity policy.
•	Monitors the employees' familiarization and awareness of potential cyber threats.
•	Trains employees on strategies preventing or responding to cyber threats.
•	Guides employees towards understanding and adhering to the best cybersecurity
practices relevant to their job responsibilities.
•	Sets appropriate procedures for reporting and investigation of all cyber-related
incidents.
•	Monitors and systematically reviews the performance and effectiveness of the
cybersecurity policy and procedures.
•	Continually improves the organization’s cybersecurity resilience based on objective
measurements.

sections.name: 20.4.2 Cybersecurity Policy
sections.content:
The Company’s Top Management treats cybersecurity management issues with the same
responsibility and importance as the entire business operations.
In Chapter 2 - APPENDIX IX, the cybersecurity policy guarantees the safety and security of
Company’s personnel and assets.

sections.name: 20.4.3 Roles, Responsibilities and Authorities
sections.content:
Cybersecurity Company Officer (CySCO):
•	Design, implement and communicate the cybersecurity policy and procedures to all
relevant interested parties.
•	Maintain an IT/OT asset inventory and manage the risks associated to them.
•	Manage user profiles & passwords in the ship network.
•	Ensure that all cybersecurity procedures are in place and documented.
•	Establish and maintain improvement plans and targets and report achievements.
•	Approve expenditure on cybersecurity-related matters, in cooperation with the GM.
•	Audit and review the cybersecurity policy and procedures.
•	Declare and investigate cybersecurity incidents.
•	Participate in Emergency Response Team.
•	Attend Management Review Meetings.
The Cybersecurity Company Officer is the Q&S Manager
with the support of the IT Dept. (outsourced)
Master:
•	Ensure that all personnel onboard implement the required procedures according to
their responsibilities regarding the cybersecurity policy.
•	Ensure that all personnel onboard observe and maintain communications'
confidentiality as required by the Company and applicable regulations.
•	Declare cybersecurity incidents.
•	Review the operation of cybersecurity controls within ship areas.
•	Request well defined necessary information security equipment and solutions.
Cybersecurity Ship Officer (CySSO):
•	Ensure that cybersecurity controls onboard are in place and documented.
•	Identify and manage cybersecurity incidents onboard.
•	Take action to prevent a cybersecurity incident from occurring or escalating, if
possible.
•	Support the IT Department for troubleshooting cyber-related incidents.
•	Maintain an IT/OT asset inventory onboard in cooperation with the IT Department.
The Cybersecurity Ship Officer is the MASTER
Company ERT members: Respond as required to a cyber incident and implement all
necessary actions.
All Company personnel: Implement the required procedures according to your
responsibilities.

sections.name: 20.4.4 Regulatory and Legislative Requirements
sections.content:
This Cybersecurity Manual complies with:
•	IMO Resolution MSC.428(98) & MSC-FAL.1/Circ.3 5 July 2017
•	The Guidelines on Cyber Security Onboard Ships - BIMCO version 1, 2, 3, 4,
and is in line with the relevant clauses of the following International Standards:
•	ISO/IEC 27001:2013
•	ISA 62443-2-1:2009
•	ISA 62443-3-3:2013
•	NIST.SP.800-53.

sections.name: 20.4.5 Sources of Cybersecurity Information
sections.content:
The Company keeps constant contact with authorities and special interest groups in order
to maintain an updated cybersecurity information database. These sources for cybersecurity
information could be:
•	Flag States
•	Classification Societies
•	Industry bodies such as OCIMF, BIMCO, INTERTANKO, ICS
•	National and International Cybersecurity Organizations (e.g. NIST-SPs, ISO
27032)
•	Specialist Cyber External Consultants
•	Cybersecurity Media and Forums.

sections.name: 20.4.6 Corporate Mobile Device Policy
sections.content:
The purpose of this policy is to set out the controls that must be in place when using mobile
devices and to mitigate the following risks:
•	Loss or theft of mobile devices, including the data on them
•	Compromise of classified information through observation by the public
•	Introduction of viruses and malware to the network
•	Loss of reputation.
Corporate mobile devices include items such as:
•	Laptops
•	Notebooks
•	Tablet devices
•	Smartphones.
The Company, through the IT Department, provides support for problem resolution and
maintenance.
Employees ashore & onboard:
•	When possible, ensure the device is transported in a protective case.
•	DO NOT leave the device unattended in public view.
•	DO NOT remove any identifying marks on the device such as a company asset tag
or serial number.
•	Ensure the device is locked when being stored and the key is not easily accessible.
•	DO NOT add removable media to the device without the approval of the IT
Department.
•	You can hold classified information on the device only when authorized and
appropriate controls (e.g., encryption) are in place.
•	DO NOT keep personal identification information within the device.
•	Ensure the device screen locks after a short period of not being used and an access
code or password is needed to unlock it.
•	DO NOT use the device for personal activities.
•	You MUST NOT install any unauthorized software or change the configuration or
setup of the device.
•	Where possible, the device will use data encryption.
•	Where applicable, virus protection secures the device.
•	DO NOT disable virus protection on the device.
•	DO NOT connect the device to non-corporate networks such as wireless or the
Internet unless a secure VPN is used.

sections.name: 20.4.7 Bring Your Own Device Policy
sections.content:
The purpose of this policy is to set out the controls that must be in place when using personal
mobile devices. Personal mobile devices include items such as:
•	Laptops
•	Notebooks
•	Tablet devices
•	Smartphones
•	Smartwatches.
Onboard
•	All personal owned mobile devices must have a password-protected screensaver.
•	It is prohibited to connect your personal mobile devices to the ship’s Business
network, IT/OT and Communication systems.
•	DO NOT store corporate data on personal devices.
•	It is prohibited to connect corporate removable media to personal mobile devices.
•	Rooted (Android), jailbroken (iOS) or unlocked mobile devices CANNOT be used.
•	Use Antivirus and Internet security software to protect your personal mobile device.
•	It is prohibited to charge your mobile devices in unauthorized stations.
Ashore
•	It is prohibited to:
	o	Connect corporate removable media (i.e. USBs) to personal mobile
devices.
	o	Store corporate data on personal devices.
	o	Use Rooted (Android), jailbroken (iOS) or unlocked mobile devices.
•	All personal owned mobile devices must have a password-protected screensaver.

sections.name: 20.5.1 Supplier Relationships
sections.content:
Information security requirements vary according to the type of contractual relationship that
exists with each supplier and the goods or services delivered.
The Company in general will apply the following:
•	The information security requirements and controls are formally documented in a
contractual agreement.
•	Separate Non-Disclosure Agreements where a more specific level of control over
confidentiality is required.
•	Appropriate due diligence in the selection and approval of new suppliers.
•	The information security provisions for existing suppliers are clearly defined.
•	Remote access by suppliers is implemented via approved methods that comply with
the Company’s information security policies.
•	Basic information security principles such as least privilege, separation of duties and
defense in depth.
•	The supplier is expected to exercise adequate control over the cybersecurity policies
and procedures used within sub-contractors who play a part in the supply chain of
delivery of goods or services to the Company.
•	Awareness training is carried out by both parties to the agreement.
The selection of required controls is based upon a comprehensive RA taking into account
information security requirements, the product or service to be supplied, its criticality to the
Company and the capabilities of the supplier.

sections.name: 20.5.2 Due Diligence
sections.content:
The Company, before contracting with a contractor/supplier, exercises due diligence in
reaching as full an understanding as possible of his information security approach and
controls.

sections.name: 20.5.3 Addressing Security Within Supplier Agreements
sections.content:
Once a potential supplier has been positively assessed with due diligence, the information
security requirements of the Company are reflected within the written contractual agreement.
This agreement takes into account the classification of any information (if used by the
Company) that is to be processed by the supplier, legal and regulatory requirements and any
additional information security controls required.

sections.name: 20.5.4 Managing Changes to Supplier Services
sections.content:
Changes to services provided by suppliers are subject to the Company’s MoC procedure. This
process includes the requirement to assess any information security implications of changes
so that the effectiveness of controls is maintained.

sections.name: 20.6 Identify Threats
sections.content:
All IT and OT systems are subject to misuse and are vulnerable to attacks. Attackers can use
vulnerabilities to access computers or network-related resources having a "potential for
unintended use". A vulnerability is not an attack but an exploitable weak point.
Cyber threats can lead to potential security violations (malicious or otherwise). They exist
because of system weaknesses.
Cyber threats for IT/OT & Communication systems are common both
onboard and ashore.
CAUTION
The table below includes the most usual threat actors, along with the types of groups capable
of committing them:
Group
Motivation
Objective
•	Reputational damage
•	Operations disruption
•	Data destruction
•	Publication of sensitive
data
•	Media attention
Activists (including
disgruntled employees)
Criminals
•	Financial gain
•	Espionage
•	Selling stolen data
•	Ransoming stolen data
•	Ransoming
system
operability
•	Transporting fraudulent
illegal cargo
Opportunists
•	Challenge/Fun/Skill
show-off
•	Financial gain
Getting through cybersecurity
defenses
•	States
•	State-sponsored
organizations
•	Terrorists
•	Gaining knowledge
•	Disruption to economies
and critical national
infrastructure
Accidental actors
No malicious motive but still
end up causing unintended
harm through bad luck, lack of
knowledge, or lack of care
•	Political/Financial
gain
•	Espionage
A cyberattack is where an attacker tries to gain unauthorized access to an IT/OT and
communication system for the purpose of theft, extortion, disruption or other nefarious
reasons. Of course, a large number of security incidents are caused by insiders – whether
through negligence or malice.

sections.name: 20.6.1.1 Phishing & Social Engineering Attacks
sections.content:
Phishing	involves sending emails that appear to be from trusted sources. The aim is to gain
your sensitive information, or to spread malware. Part confidence trick and part hacking,
phishing is one of the easiest (and therefore, the most common) ways to breach a Company’s
security. Think of it as a way to find out your password – a highly effective password attack.
Spear phishing	 uses a more focused approach. These attacks require a bit more research
on an individual or a target user group. For example, with a little online research, a phisher
can identify your colleague’s email addresses and send what appears to be a legitimate email
from a trusted source instructing your users to download a file (malware), or even hand over
the login details to a key business application.
•Train the users on the correct protocols for password security.
•Hover the mouse over URL link to check the legitimacy of the web
CAUTION

sections.name: 20.6.1.2 Password Attacks & Credential Reuse
sections.content:
Despite the risks being well known, people fail to use	strong passwords, inadvertently give
them away to phishing scammers or scribble them on bits of paper.
A	hacker	will use an array of password hacking techniques, from using lists of common ‘weak’
passwords, to sophisticated ‘Rainbow table’ attacks, using previously hacked/cracked	lists of
hashed passwords.
•Educate your users on phishing methods.
•Encourage & enforce the	use of strong, unique passwords.
•Implement an account lockout policy.
•Prohibit the use of default passwords.
CAUTION

sections.name: 20.6.1.3 Malware attack
sections.content:
Malicious software can be described as unwanted software that is installed in a system without
the user’s consent. It can attach itself to legitimate code and propagate. It can lurk in useful
applications or replicate itself across the Internet.

sections.name: 20.6.1.4 Denial-of-Service Attacks
sections.content:
There’s a variety of	DoS and DDoS (Distributed Denial of Service) attacks which can have
devastating consequences. The most common are teardrop attack, smurf attack, TCP SYN
flood attack, ping-of-death, and botnets.
DoS & DDoS attacks hurt businesses by flooding	target web servers with requests	– stopping
regular users connecting. This means	website downtime, disappointed customers, reputation
damage and can even result in data losses & compensation payouts.
•If you don’t have “always-on” DoS protection, make sure you do
have protocols in place to help you stop an attack, or at least
minimise the impact.
•It is not enough to hope that your firewalls and ISP are able to stop
the heavy loads that attackers use today. There are 3 main
options to consider for DoS protection:
	o	On-premise protection to identify, filter, detect and protect
your network.
	o	Cloud-based counteraction to deflect, absorb, reroute and
scrub.
	o	Hybrid solution (combining on-prem and cloud DoS
protection).
CAUTION

sections.name: 20.6.1.5 Man-in-the-Middle (MitM)
sections.content:
A MitM attack	is when a hacker inserts themselves between two legitimate hosts. It’s the cyber
equivalent of eavesdropping on a private conversation. In fact, an eavesdropping attack is a
common type of attack itself. But the MitM attack goes a step further since it has the added
malevolence of disguising itself as one, or both of the people speaking.
This means it doesn’t just intercept and listen into messages between clients and servers. It
can also change the messages and plant requests that appear to be from a legitimate source.
These types of attacks are notoriously difficult to detect	– but there are preventative
measures.
•Use SSL certificates (HTTPS, not just HTTP) to enhance security
(and user trust) in Company’s website/extranet.
•Consider an Intrusion Detection System (IDS).
•Set-up a VPN to add additional layers of protection over Wi-Fi (and
other confidential networks).
CAUTION

sections.name: 20.6.1.6 Structured Query Language (SQL) Injections
sections.content:
An SQL injection is when malicious code is inserted into an SQL database. For an attacker, it
can be as simple as submitting malicious code into a website’s search box.
Once the code’s been unleashed, it can read, modify or delete the data. Some SQL attacks
can even shutdown a database and issue commands to the operating system.
•Apply a least-privilege permissions model in the databases.
•Stick to stored procedures (exclude dynamic SQL) and prepared
statements (parameterized queries).
•Validate SQL data inputs against a whitelist.
CAUTION

sections.name: 20.6.1.7 Zero-day Exploit
sections.content:
If a user uncovers a security risk in a program, they may well notify the software company so
they can develop and issue a security patch to fix the issue. But they may also share their
discovery online too.
This well-meaning user (who only wanted to warn others) has just exposed a vulnerability to
the world. While the software developers rush to fix the problem, hackers get busy exploiting
it.
By their nature, zero-day attacks are usually the most difficult to defend against, since the
precise nature of the attack is only available after it has happened. These vulnerabilities are
not only highly prized by cyber criminals, but nation states too.
•Keep operating systems and application software up to date.
•Use virtual LANS to protect transmitted data by making use of a
firewall.
•Protect against wireless malware attacks with a secure Wi-Fi
system.
•Stick to websites with SSL certificates.
•DO NOT use cracked/unknown applications.
CAUTION

sections.name: 20.6.1.8 Cross-site Scripting (XSS)
sections.content:
This attack usually runs in conjunction with social engineering because it requires a user to
visit a web page where the hacker has inserted malicious script.
When you land on an infected web page, the malicious payload can leave you exposed to a
variety of unpleasant consequences. In a worst-case scenario, the XSS attack can access
webcams, microphones, log keystrokes and even take remote control over the user’s machine.
The most common vehicle is JavaScript	as it is so widely used across the web.
•Ensure users are educated on phishing techniques.
•Sanitize the data input by users with an HTTP request.
•Run XXS vulnerability tests.
CAUTION

sections.name: 20.6.1.9 Drive-by-downloads
sections.content:
A drive-by download attack can take advantage of an operating system, web browser or app
that has vulnerabilities (due to a lack of security updates). It can be transmitted when the
user simply views an email, pop-up or website.
•Keep your OS and browsers updated.
•Stick to trusted sites you would normally use.
•Keep only apps and programs you need – the more plug-ins, the
more weak spots you may have.
CAUTION

sections.name: 20.6.2 Cyber-attack Stages
sections.content:
Cyberattacks occur in 4 stages:
1.	Survey / Reconnaissance: Attackers use:
	o	Open/public sources to gain information about the Company, ships, or
seafarer to prepare for a cyber attack.
	o	Social media, technical forums, and hidden properties in websites,
documents, and publications to identify technical, procedural, and physical
vulnerabilities.
2.	Delivery: Attackers may attempt to access Company and ship systems and data
remotely or directly from within the Company or ships. Examples of the methods
used include:
	o	Company online services, including cargo or consignment tracking systems
	o	Sending emails containing malicious files or links to malicious websites to
personnel
	o	Providing infected removable media, for example, as part of a software
update for an onboard system
	o	Creating false or misleading websites encouraging the personnel's
disclosure of user account information.
3.	Breach: The extent to which an attacker can breach a Company or ship system
depends on the vulnerability the attacker finds and the attack method he employs.
Depending on the breach significance, an attacker may be able to:
	o	Make changes that affect the system's operation.
	o	Gain access to sensitive data, e.g., cargo manifests or crew/passenger
lists.
	o	Gain complete control over a system, e.g., main engine.
A breach might not result in any apparent changes to the equipment
status.
CAUTION
4.	Effect: The attacker's motivation and objectives determine the impact his
actions have on the Company or ship system and data. An attacker may explore
systems, expand access and/or make sure that he can return to the system to:
	o	Cause complete denial of service on business systems.
	o	Enable other forms of crime, for example, piracy, theft, and fraud.
	o	Manipulate crew or passenger/lists, cargo manifests, stow plans, etc.
This manipulation subsequently allows the fraudulent transport of illegal
cargo or may facilitate thefts.
	o	Disrupt normal operation of the Company's and ship's systems, for example,
by deleting critical information or overloading the Company's systems.
	o	Install permanent tools or a key logger to keep and maintain access to the
system.
	o	Execute new attacks.
The users of IT and OT systems onboard and ashore must:
•Know the cybersecurity threats.
•Receive training to identify and mitigate such risks.
CAUTION

sections.name: 20.7 Identify Vulnerabilities
sections.content:
The Company:
•	Adopts a risk management approach to assess and mitigate the risks associated with
the threat actors relevant to its activities.
•	Prioritizes cybersecurity risks.
•	Assesses potential threats.
•	Assesses the systems and procedures onboard and ashore to map the robustness
to handle the current threat level.
•	Decides on appropriate and proportionate investment in a security controls portfolio
to mitigate risks with the most significant potential impact.
These vulnerability assessments, resulting in a strategy centered around the key risks,
involve:
•	Identification and evaluation of essential or sensitive assets and infrastructure
considered essential to protect as well as the external infrastructure systems on
which they depend.
•	Identification of the ship's business processes using the assets and infrastructure to
assess the criticality of assets and understand any internal/external dependencies.
•	Identification and assessment of risks arising from possible threats to assets and
infrastructure, vulnerabilities, and the likelihood of their occurrence, to establish the
need for and to prioritize security measures.
•	Identification, assessment, selection, and prioritization of security controls and
procedural changes, based on their costs, the level of effectiveness in reducing the
risk, and any impact on the ship's operations.
•	Identification of the overall residual risk acceptability, including human factors and
weaknesses in the infrastructure, policies, and procedures, based on the selected
security controls.

sections.name: 20.7.1 Determination of Vulnerability Onboard
sections.content:
General RA guidance:
•Standalone systems are less vulnerable to cyberattacks than
systems attached to uncontrolled networks or directly to the
internet.
•Understand how critical shipboard systems might connect to
uncontrolled networks.
•Consider the human element since personnel actions initiate
CAUTION
many incidents.
Onboard vulnerable IT/OT systems are included in:
•	Bridge systems
•	Cargo and loading Management Systems
•	Communication systems
•	Access control systems
•	Propulsion and machinery management and power control systems
•	Passenger servicing and management systems
•	Passenger facing public networks
•	Administrative and crew welfare systems.
Digital communication helps conduct business, manage operations and stay in touch with the
Office. Furthermore, critical ship systems essential for the safety of navigation, power, and
cargo management are extensively digitalized and connected to the Internet for a wide variety
of functions.
Consider the risks of misunderstood, unknown, and uncoordinated remote access to an
operating ship as a critical part of the RA.
The following are common cyber vulnerabilities:
•	Obsolete and unsupported operating systems
•	Outdated or missing antivirus software and malware protection
•	Inadequate security configurations
•	The use of default administrator accounts and passwords
•	Ineffective network management not based on the least privilege principle
•	Shipboard computer networks lacking boundary protection measures and network
segmentation
•	Safety-critical equipment or systems permanently connected to the shore side
•	Inadequately trained and/or skilled staff to manage cyber risks
•	Missing, inadequate, or untested contingency plans and procedures
•	Inadequate access controls for third parties, including contractors and service
providers.
Consider the following:
•	The maker's and service provider's cybersecurity awareness and procedures
•	The maturity of their cybersecurity awareness and procedures.
Shoreside and onboard personnel may be unaware of how some
equipment providers maintain remote access to equipment and its
network system.
WARNING
The Company shall:
•Ask these companies for a cybersecurity policy, including training
and governance procedures for the accessible IT and OT
systems onboard.
•Challenge the internal cyber network security governance.
•Get a cybersecurity assurance when considering future contracts
and services.
CAUTION

sections.name: 20.7.2 Determination of Vulnerability Ashore
sections.content:
IT Department:
•	Assess the exposure risk and extent of ICT systems exposure to cyberattacks.
•	Consider the ICT infrastructure at the Office, including Server Room and desk
workstations vulnerable to cyberattacks. These systems' cybersecurity follows the
same principles as the onboard systems.
•	Consider the network's physical layout and vital network devices' physical location,
including servers, switches, firewalls, and cabling. This helps restrict access and
maintain the physical security of the network installation and control network entry
points.
•	Run periodic system vulnerability scans, seeking gaps in protective coverage and
system configuration.
•	Identify and evaluate each system's connections with reported vulnerabilities to
determine those vulnerabilities' criticality and prioritize patching those systems
accordingly.
•	Use a process feeding recognized and discovered vulnerabilities from scans and
asset assessments back to the RA process for prioritization and mitigation actions.
Ashore vulnerable ICT systems include:
•	Web/Application/File Servers
•	Workstations/thin-clients
•	Network systems (Wi-Fis, switches, routers, firewalls, IDS, IPS)
•	Printers/scanners
•	Mobile devices (smartphones, tablets).
Any network design must include infrastructure for administering and managing the network.
This may include installing network management software on dedicated workstations and
servers providing file sharing, email, and other services to the network.

sections.name: 20.8 Risk Assessment (RA)
sections.content:
To map robustness to handle the current cyber threats, start the RA process by assessing the
systems onboard and ashore.
IT Department: Test and assess the IT & OT systems as follows:
•	Identify existing technical and procedural controls to protect both the vulnerable
onboard and office IT & OT systems, the specific vulnerabilities, including human
factors, and the policies and procedures governing these systems' use.
•	Identify and evaluate critical shipboard operations.
•	Identify possible cyber incidents, their impact on crucial shipboard operations, and
the likelihood of their occurrence.
•	Prioritize and establish mitigating measures.
•	Perform periodic RAs by revisiting operating assumptions regarding capabilities and
system monitoring needs.
•	Exercise due care and diligence concerning cybersecurity assets, risks, and
protective systems, providing appropriate capabilities yielding protections deemed
adequate against expected threats.
•	Incorporate all cybersecurity actions, automated systems, and risk management
processes into a single Management System.

sections.name: 20.8.1 Activity Phases
sections.content:
Phase 1: Pre-assessment activities
Before a cybersecurity assessment:
•	Identify critical IT/OT & Communication systems.
•	Map the key functions and systems and their potential impact levels.
•	Identify primary providers of the critical IT & OT equipment.
•	Review detailed documentation of the critical OT & IT systems and their interfaces.
•	Identify cybersecurity points-of-contact at every provider and establish working
relationships.
•	Review detailed documentation of the IT & OT systems maintenance and support.
•	Establish contractual requirements and obligations the Company may have for
network and equipment maintenance and support.
•	Support RA with external experts to develop detailed plans and include makers and
service providers.
Phase 2: Ship / Office assessment
The goal of assessing a ship's/Office's network and its systems and devices is to identify
vulnerabilities that may lead to loss of service of the equipment, system, or network. These
vulnerabilities and weaknesses may include:
•	Technical issues, such as software defects
•	Outdated or unpatched systems
•	Design issues, such as access management or implementation errors.
The activities must include:
•	A build and configuration review of computers, servers, routers, and firewalls
•	Reviews of all available cybersecurity documentation and procedures for connected
IT/OT systems and devices.
Phase 3: Vulnerability review
•	Examine each identified vulnerability for its potential impact and probability of its
exploitation.
•	Identify recommended technical and/or procedural corrective actions.
Phase 4: Provider debriefing
•	Send relevant findings to the providers of the affected systems.
•	Analyze the findings with external experts to achieve a full risk and technical
understanding of the problem.
•	Ensure that the provider's remediation plan is comprehensive and the correct solution
to eliminate the vulnerabilities is available.

sections.name: 20.8.2 Impact Assessment
sections.content:
The Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability (CIA) model provides a framework for assessing
the vulnerability to and the impact of:
•	Unauthorized access and disclosure of information or data about the ship, crew,
cargo, and passengers
•	Loss of integrity, which would modify or destroy information and data relating to the
ship's safe and efficient operation and administration
•	Loss of availability due to destruction of the information and data and/or the
service/operation disruption of the ship's systems.

sections.name: 20.8.3 Reducing / Managing the Risk
sections.content:
The Company:
•	Uses a risk management method to contain and contextualize all cybersecurity and
related risk issues into a risk Management System.
•	Seeks a sustainable and acceptable risk posture that is economical, feasible, and
supportable.
•	Communicates information system and data risks relating to financial stability, brand
reputation, and operations integrity in terms that its stakeholders understand.
•	Defines a risk tolerance strategy by monitoring the risk indicators supporting that
strategy.
•	Links security controls to the compliance reporting requirements to indicate the
degree of attainable security and not simple compliance.
•	Considers separately how to deal with occasions when the usual controls are
invalidated, e.g.:
	o	When there is no control over persons with access to onboard systems.
	o	During dry-docking.
	o	When taking over a new ship. It is impossible to know if malicious software
is available in the onboard systems.
	o	When third-party technicians connect via remote access for maintenance,
reading system data, or troubleshooting.
	o	When service providers or authorities connect removable media directly to
an onboard system.
Cybersecurity defenses may be technical and focused on ensuring that onboard systems are
resilient to cyberattacks. Company policies, safety management or security procedures, and
access controls may also cover these defenses procedurally.
Both technical and procedural controls must be compatible with the CIA model for protecting
data and information.
Prioritize the implementation of cybersecurity controls, focusing first on
the defenses or combinations of defenses offering the most significant
benefit.
CAUTION

sections.name: 20.9.1 Employee Screening Check
sections.content:
The intention of employee screening is to minimize the cyber risk to the organization arising
from accidental or deliberate malpractice, especially in critical cybersecurity roles.
The Company performs due care and due diligence when hiring new employees, particularly
those that will operate or engaged in cybersecurity positions. The screening checks may
include Cybersecurity work references, ICT academic and professional qualifications.

sections.name: 20.9.2 Employee Termination and Change of Employment
sections.content: IT Manager: Upon employee’s termination, retrieve all corporate equipment.

sections.name: 20.10.1 IT / OT and Communication Systems Inventory
sections.content:
A complete and accurate inventory of hardware and	sSoftware information across the
organization is the first step for a strong, robust, and mature cyber risk management system.
The Company keeps an up-to-date hardware and software inventory (form CS 001 and CS
002) for all IT, OT and Communication Asset Systems onboard and ashore in a way that:
•	Maps all cyber related critical assets.
•	Monitors the maintenance of critical systems.
•	Identifies and appoints Asset Owners.
•	Monitors the lifecycle of the equipment.
•	Monitors and controls the hardware and software deployment on its systems to:
	o	Identify cybersecurity threats.
	o	Evaluate existing cybersecurity controls.
	o	Assess vulnerabilities including from third parties.
	o	Perform qualitative RAs.
In Chapter 10 par. 10.2.5 and Appendix II of the UMMS, the critical equipment related to
cybersecurity are described.

sections.name: 20.10.2 IT / OT Acceptable Use Policy
sections.content:
All employees ashore & onboard:
•	You are expected to comply fully with all of the cybersecurity policies and procedures
that are in place and to report any breaches of these policies of which they may
become aware.
•	Anyone breaching the cybersecurity policy may be subject to disciplinary action.
•	Protect and use only their user credentials (user account and password, access
token).
•	Access only IT/OT systems to which they have been given access.
•	Protect any classified material sent, received, stored or processed by you.
•	NOT attempt to bypass or subvert any IT/OT system cybersecurity controls or to use
them for any purpose other than that intended.
•	DO NOT leave your computer unattended such that unauthorised access can be
gained to office/ship’s IT/OT systems via your account.
•	DO NOT remove equipment or information from the office/ship’s premises without
appropriate approval.
•	Inform immediately the CSO / Cybersecurity Company Officer ashore and/or Master
/ Cybersecurity Ship Officer onboard, if you detect, suspect or witness a cybersecurity
incident that may be a breach of security or if you observe any suspected
cybersecurity weaknesses in systems or services.
•	DO NOT introduce viruses or other malware into IT/OT systems or network.
•	DO NOT attempt to disable anti-virus protection provided at your computer or IT/OT
systems.
•	You must always comply with the legal, statutory or contractual obligations relevant
to your role.

sections.name: 20.10.3 Information Classification Procedure
sections.content:
The Company maintains inventories of all-important information and operation assets upon
which it relies and protects the information it holds and processes by using classification
controls appropriate to the sensitivity of the information involved.
This procedure sets out the details of the scheme to be adopted and the criteria applied in
deciding which level of protection to apply to any given information asset.
This control applies to all information and operation systems, people and processes,
including managers, employees, suppliers, contractors and other third parties who have
access to the Company’s systems.

sections.name: 20.10.3.1 Classification Scheme
sections.content:
The classes of information are:
•	Public (or unclassified): Much of the information held by the Company is freely
available to the public via established publication methods. Such items of information
have no classification and will not be assigned a formal owner or inventoried.
•	Protected: This is typically information which is relatively private in nature, either to
an individual or to the Company and, whilst its loss or disclosure is unlikely to result
in significant consequences, it would be undesirable.
•	Confidential: This is reserved for information which is highly sensitive and would
cause major reputation and financial loss if it were lost or wrongly disclosed.

sections.name: 20.10.3.2 Information Labelling Procedure
sections.content:
In order to ensure that the correct controls are applied to the information and operation
system assets, so that all employees and third parties (where applicable) are aware of how
that information must be managed, the following system of protective marking may be used:
•	Printed Reports such as:
	o	A watermark, clearly visible on every page of the document.
	o	The classification is shown clearly on the front page and in the header of
every page.
	o	A stamp to mark each page with the security classification.
•	Screen Displays may include a warning:
	o	Upon logon which requires user acknowledgement.
	o	Upon entering an area with a higher classification of information for saving
or printing data.
•	Recorded Media with classified data are labelled externally with the security
classification of the most sensitive data on the media.
•	Electronic Messages with classified information within:
	o	Emails with sensitive or confidential information must include the
classification level.
	o	An attachment, the classification is clearly stated at the header of the
document.
•	Classified File Transfers: The recipient is clearly informed of the classification level
of the information being transmitted, before it is sent.

sections.name: 20.10.4 Management of Removable Media
sections.content:
Where removable media of any format (CD, DVD, memory stick etc.) is used to store sensitive
data, assess whether an alternative, more secure method can be used and if not, how best to
secure the current method so that the risk is minimised.
Such methods may include:
•	Transfer of data to third parties e.g., suppliers, contractors, other agencies
•	Taking information home to work on
•	Backups of data in addition to scheduled server backups
•	Transfer of data between devices e.g., USB to ECDIS.
In the event that an existing method is not in the above list and contravenes the cybersecurity
policy, identify an alternative method of achieving the desired end result.
The following tools are available and supported by the IT Department:
•	Remote access via well-known relevant software
•	Encrypted memory stick
•	Secure file transfer.
Where removable media is requested for legitimate purposes, use the following procedure.

sections.name: 20.10.4.1 User Request is Received
sections.content:
The IT Support Team will determine whether the use of removable media is the most
appropriate method of achieving the business purpose that the user has.

sections.name: 20.10.4.2 Order New or Allocate Existing Removable Media
sections.content:
•	Use any new or re-usable removable media in stock in preference to ordering new.
•	Wipe any existing data in re-used removable media.
•	There is a protected spreadsheet that holds the following information about issued
removable media:
	o	Asset Number
	o	Serial Number
	o	Password
	o	Allocated User
	o	Date of issue.
•	Use the IT/OT inventory spreadsheet and create a new line for new removable media
or find the correct line for re-issued removable media.

sections.name: 20.10.4.3 Set Removable Media Password
sections.content:
Always set a password for classified removable media. This must be at least 8 characters,
have at least one capital letter and include a number.
IT Department: Provide the guidelines on how to do this.

sections.name: 20.10.4.4 Record Information in IT / OT Inventory Spreadsheet
sections.content:
Add the name of the allocated user to the spreadsheet and the date the removable media was
issued.

sections.name: 20.10.4.5 Inform User of Key Facts
sections.content:
Email the user that has requested the removable media. If several have been requested,
contact each person individually.
IT Department:
•	Where removable media are password protected, make the user aware that:
	o	The data on the removable media may be fully encrypted.
	o	The data WILL NOT be accessible without the password.
	o	If the password is lost, the data WILL NOT be recoverable.
	o	He MUST NOT write the password down or keep it with the removable
media.
	o	He MUST NOT change the password. If he does, the IT Support Desk will
not be able to help him if he forgets it.
	o	He must inform the IT Department if the removable media is lost.
•	Obtain email confirmation before the removable media is sent out that they have read
and understood the above. Save the confirmation email on an IT shared drive.

sections.name: 20.10.4.6 Send Removable Media to User
sections.content:
•	Send the removable media to the user by internal post or deliver it by hand.
•	DO NOT include any passwords.

sections.name: 20.10.4.7 Provide User with Password in a Secure Way
sections.content:
•	Provide the password to the user by phone once they have received the removable
media.
•	Verify the user’s identity.

sections.name: 20.10.5 Removable Media Policy
sections.content:
This policy defines the proper/expected usage of removable media (USB sticks, CDs/DVDs)
in the Company's systems.

sections.name: 20.10.5.1 Security of Removable Media
sections.content:
Ashore
•	The use of unauthorized removable media devices is prohibited. Unauthorized
devices are blocked.
•	Transferring information to corporate PCs from third parties occurs via a dedicated
“visitor” PC/laptop, using an authorized media device, with the IT Department's
guidance. The “visitor’s” PC/laptop has no network connection.
•	Cameras and external hard disks are allowed only with the IT Department's
authorization.
•	It is prohibited to charge mobile phones on corporate PCs.
•	There is an automatic removable media scanning procedure when connected to
corporate PCs and laptops.
All employees:
•Ensure the appropriate use and security of information stored in
removable media devices.
•Store media in a safe place to minimize physical risk, loss, or
theft.
•In case of loss, immediately inform the IT Department for their
replacement.
•DO NOT use damaged or faulty removable media devices- request their replacement.
CAUTION
Onboard
•	DO NOT use unauthorized removable media devices on IT & OT equipment.
•	C/O and C/E: Ensure scanning of service engineers' removable media (such as
USBs) for viruses on a business PC/Laptop before plugging them into any system.
•	Block all USB ports on IT equipment for unauthorized removable media devices.
•	IT Department: Use removable media blockers on all IT removable media and
network ports to restrict unauthorized removable media devices and if applicable with
the use of centralized software platform.
•	Use removable media blockers for all visible and accessible ports (i.e. USB, RJ-45)
of the following OT equipment:
	o	ECDIS Work Station 1 and Work Station 2
	o	Cargo Monitoring System (if applicable)
	o	VDR
	o	Loadicator PC
	o	Alarm Monitoring System.
•	Master and C/E:
	o	Keep the above OT systems' removable media and network ports blocked
and unblock them only for business or troubleshooting purposes, using a
special key in cooperation with the IT Department.
	o	Request the replacement of any missing or damaged removable
media/network port.
	o	Distribute removable media and network port unblocking keys to the
successors during a changeover.
	o	Confirm this in handover checklists.
•	Transfer of information to ship's PCs from third parties occurs via a dedicated “visitor”
PC using an authorized media device. “Visitor” PCs have no network connection.
DO NOT charge personal phones on ship equipment with USB ports.
CAUTION

sections.name: 20.10.5.2 Authorized Removable Media
sections.content:
•	Each ship may have a number of authorized removable media for specific purposes.
An indicative list of authorized removable media, their purpose, and the person
responsible are shown in the following table:

•	Distribute authorized removable media to the successors during the handover
