•	IT Department:
	o	Configure the authorized USB sticks, where applicable, with password
protection and with an embedded antivirus solution.
	o	Update virus and malware checking software when you connect the
removable media device to a networked IT PC.
•	Responsible crew:
	o	Ensure the appropriate use and security of information stored in the
authorized removable media devices.
	o	Store media in a safe place to minimize physical risk, loss, or theft.

sections.name: 20.10.6 Disposal of IT/OT equipment
sections.content:
Log requests to securely dispose of IT/OT assets with the IT or/and Technical Department via
telephone, email or online. The owner of the device must inform the IT or/and Technical
Department for the need of the equipment disposal.
Provide the following details:
•	Requester name, role, department and contact details
•	The type of equipment to be disposed of
•	The serial number of the equipment (e.g., PC), if available
•	The classification of the information held on the equipment, if known
•	The location of the equipment
•	The reason for the equipment needing to be disposed of
•	When the equipment will be available for collection.
The owner of the device must ensure that any required backups have been made of the data
prior to requesting disposal.
According to the type of equipment and the contractual arrangements with third parties, the IT
Department will decide how best to dispose of the media, as following:
Ashore
•	Local Disposal: Where available, local facilities will be used to securely dispose of
certain types of equipment. Media that may be locally disposed of may include:
	o	PCs, Servers, Network devices
	o	Laptops, Phones and tablets.
	o	USB memory sticks
	o	Hard disks
	o	CDs and DVDs
	o	Solid state storage devices
	o	Floppy disks
Only approved equipment e.g., a disk shredder may be used for local disposal.
•	Using a Third Party: For devices and media that require specialist equipment to
securely destroy them a third party must be used.
Onboard
Disposal of e-waste is being carried our as described in company’s ship specific
Garbage Management Plan (GMP). Separate bins, drums, etc. are used for all e-
Waste items that are collected and stored in a locked area.

sections.name: 20.11.1 Access Control ashore and onboard
sections.content:
•	Access is granted using the principle of ‘Least Privilege’.
•	Each user is identified by a unique user identity so that users can be linked to and
made responsible for their actions.
•	The use of group identities is only permitted where they are suitable for the work
carried out (e.g., training accounts or service accounts).
•	Records of user access will be used to provide evidence for security incident
investigations.
•	Users have network access in accordance with the Company’s access control
procedures and requirements defined by their roles.
•	Staff who access Company’s network remotely shall only be authenticated using the
approved remote access authentication mechanism.
•	Removable media blockers are used on all physically accessible computers and
network ports.
IT Department: Ensure that:
•	Removable media (i.e USB type A/B/C) and network (RJ-45) ports are physically
blocked with the use of removable media blockers and disabled, if applicable, with
the use of access control software.
•	Removable media and network ports are only enabled for specified business
reasons.
•	Network administrators group together information services, users and information
systems as appropriate to achieve the required segregation on networks.
•	Only authorized personnel have access to system utilities. Access must be revoked
when there is no longer a business reason for access.
•	All user workstations are configured to lock automatically after a period of inactivity
to reduce the risk of unauthorized access.
All Company’s users:
•	Confirm that you are an authorized user at logon.
•	Have a unique identifier which MUST NOT be shared with other users.
•	Change your passwords at frequent intervals and in accordance with the password
management policy.

sections.name: 20.11.1.1 User Registration and Deregistration
sections.content:
•	A request for access to the Company’s network and computer systems is submitted
to the IT Department for approval. The principle of segregation of duties is applied.
•	Each approved user account has a unique user name that is not shared with others.
•	The user receives via secure means an initial strong password created during
account setup. The user must change the initial password during the first use.
•	Access rights and permissions must only be granted based on standard role-based
profiles according to the system owner's accountability. This applies to:
	o	New employees
	o	Existing employee position change
	o	Internship employees
	o	Shore-assignment employees.
•	When an employee leaves the Company under normal circumstances, his access to
information systems and data is valid up to his last working day. In exceptional
circumstances, the relevant Manager may request to revoke the employee's access
rights before the termination notice.
•	The respective Department must submit a request to the IT Department to revoke the
employee's access rights upon leave (including interns and shore assignments).

sections.name: 20.11.1.2 Removal or Adjustment of Access Rights
sections.content:
•	When a user is taking on a new role in addition to their existing one.
•	In case a user acquires a different role than the existing one.
•	Administrators are not permitted to change their own user accounts or permissions.

sections.name: 20.11.1.3 Management of Privileged Access Rights
sections.content:
•	Privileged access rights such as those associated with administrator-level accounts
are identified for each system or network and tightly controlled.
•	Admin level permissions are allocated to trained individuals whose roles require
them.
•	Admin-level rights are provided only to individuals whose roles require them.

sections.name: 20.11.1.4 Employees Remote access
sections.content:
For the use of network communication equipment on non-company’s owned PCs or devices
connected to the Company’s IT/OT systems the following are required:
•	Specific approval from the IT Department before connecting any equipment to the
Company’s network.
•	Remote access to the network is implemented only via VPN connection. The request
is always made via the IT Department.
•	The company will supply users with remote access software.
•	Non-company-provided PC’s to access the corporate network is permitted, as long
as the PC meets the following criteria:
	o	It has up-to-date antivirus software installed
	o	Its software patch levels are current.
•	Two factor authentication for remote access support or teleworking, when feasible, is
used in order to reduce the risk of unauthorized access from the Internet.

sections.name: 20.11.1.5 Contractors / Suppliers Access to the Company’s Network
sections.content:
IT Department:
•	Permission to connect to the Company’s network is mandatory. Maintain a log of
activity.
•	DO NOT reveal details of how to access the Company’s network.
•	On termination or renewal of a contract, contractors or suppliers must immediately
notify the IT Department so that the access can be updated or ceased.
•	Manage all permissions and access methods.
•	Disable remote access software and remote user accounts when not in use.
Contractors / Suppliers onboard access:
•	Brief, accordingly, the Master / C/E / CySSO on the work plan (tasks MUST NOT
affect the operational status of the ship).
•	DO NOT access (physical or logical) any ship’s IT/OT & Communications
equipment/system irrelevant to the work purpose. If needed, privileged access will be
on a need to know basis under the supervision of the CySSO.
•	DO NOT carry and use any electronic equipment (i.e., Laptop, tablet, etc.) unrelated
to the predefined tasks.
•	Conduct data transfer to ship’s IT/OT systems via a dedicated authorized ship’s
media device. If the latter procedure is not applicable, use any necessary electronic
equipment for the related task, which has been updated with the most recent patches
and security requirements (malware free).
•	On work completion, debrief the Master/ CySSO, as applicable, with the deliverable, such as configuration/maintenance documentation, spare IT/OT parts and reassure
them that tasks WILL NOT affect the operational status of the ship.
Contractors / Suppliers remote access:
•	Access to external vendors is allowed to specific systems in order for them to provide
remote support on the Company’s business applications, as described in the
respective maintenance and support contracts. The systems each vendor can
connect to are pre-defined and restricted according to the support requirements.
•	In case contractors or suppliers would like to gain remote access to the Company’s
network, they must inform the IT Department. In case of employment termination, the
supplier must be immediately informed accordingly.
•	Use, where feasible, two factor authentication for:
	o	Remote Network access
	o	Remote System monitoring and maintenance.

sections.name: 20.11.1.6 Review of User Access Rights
sections.content:
On a regular basis (at least annually), asset and system owners are required to review who
has access to their areas of responsibility and the level of access in place in order to identify:
•	People who must not have access (e.g., former employees)
•	User accounts with more access than required by their role
•	User accounts with incorrect role allocations
•	User accounts that do not provide adequate identification e.g., generic or shared
accounts.
IT Department: Carry out a review of user accounts with privileged access regularly to ensure
that this policy is being complied with.

sections.name: 20.11.2 Password Policy
sections.content:
Ashore & Onboard
The Company, whether using single or multi-factor authentication, requires the quality of user
passwords in all networks and systems to apply the following parameters:
Parameter
Value
Minimum length
8
Maximum length
16
Re-use cycle
Cannot be the same as the previous passwords
Characters Required
At least 1 capital letter - 1 lower - 1 symbol - 1 number
Password similarity
New password cannot share more than 3 characters in the same
position as the old password
Change Frequency
At least every 180 days
Account lockout
On 5 incorrect logon attempts
Account lockout action
Account must be re-enabled by IT Department
System Control
Checks above prerequisites and rejects incompatible
passwords
Other controls
Password cannot contain the user name
All employees:
•	Use a strong password in line with the rules set out in this policy.
•	DO NOT use dictionary words or acronyms.
•	Change the temporary password when connected to the system for the first time.
•	NEVER tell anyone your password or allow anyone else to use your account.
•	DO NOT record the password in writing or electronically e.g., in a file or email.
•	Avoid using the same password for other user accounts, either personal or business-
related.
•	Ensure that any PC or device you leave unattended connected to the network is
locked or logged out.
•	Leave nothing on display that may contain access information such as login names
and passwords.
•	Inform the IT Department of any changes to your role and access requirements.
Onboard
•	System passwords are available in an encrypted database, accessible only by the
Master and the C/E. The Office updates the password database and distributes them
automatically to all ships.
•	It is forbidden for the ship's crew to change the ship's systems' account passwords
(IT or OT).
During a handover, the distribution of handover passwords must ensure their confidentiality.

sections.name: 20.12 Data Security
sections.content:
Data in transit or data in motion, is data actively moving from one location to another such as
across the internet or through a private network. Data protection in transit is the protection of
this data while it’s traveling from network to network or being transferred from a local storage
device to a cloud storage device. Data at rest is data stored on a hard drive, laptop, flash drive, or archived/stored in some other
way. Data protection at rest aims to secure inactive data stored on any device or network.
The risk profile for data in transit or data at rest depends on the security measures that are in
place to secure data in either state.
The Company implements the following controls for protecting its data ashore & onboard:
•	Maintains an inventory of sensitive systems.
•	Removes sensitive data or systems not regularly accessed.
•	Monitors and blocks unauthorized network traffic.
•	Only allows access to authorized cloud storage or email providers, where is used.
•	Monitors and detects any unauthorized use of encryption.
•	Manages and protects data on removable media storage devices.
•	Manages system’s external removable media’s configurations.
Encryption plays a major role in data protection and is a popular tool for securing data both in
transit and at rest. Encryption is seriously considered in the following scenarios:
•	On mobile devices such as laptops, tablets and smartphones
•	Where classified data is transmitted across communications lines like the Internet by
using connections such as HTTPS, SSL, TLS, FTPS
•	For sensitive files prior to storing them and/or choose to encrypt the storage drive
itself
•	For protection of data on removable media
•	For data storage in the cloud, if applicable
•	For systems password protection
•	For remote access on systems by using TLS for Virtual Private Networks.
It is vital that cryptographic keys are protected from modification, loss, destruction and
unauthorised disclosure. A lifecycle approach will be taken to key management which will
require the creation of specific procedures to cover the following stages:
•	Key generation
•	Distribution of keys to point of use
•	Storage at point of use
•	Backup as protection against loss
•	Recovery in the event of loss
•	Updating keys once expired
•	Revoking if compromised
•	Archiving once expired
•	Destroying when no longer required
•	Logging and auditing of key management related activities.
These procedures will take account of the specific circumstances in which encryption will be
used.

sections.name: 20.13 Physical Security
sections.content:
This control applies to all systems onboard and ashore, people and processes that constitute
the Company’s information IT/OT systems, including employees, suppliers and other third
parties who have access to the Company systems.

sections.name: 20.13.1 Secure Areas
sections.content:
•	Physical security begins with the Ship/Office itself and an assessment of perimeter
vulnerability is conducted. A Ship/Office has appropriate control mechanisms in place
for the classification of information and equipment that is stored within it, such as:
	o	Alarms fitted and activated outside working hours
	o	Window and door locks
	o	Window bars on lower floor levels
	o	Access control mechanisms fitted to all accessible doors (where codes are
utilized, they must be regularly changed and known only to those people
authorized to access the area/building)
	o	CCTV cameras
	o	Protection against damage from e.g., fire, flood, vandalism.
•	Identification and access tools/passes (e.g., badges, keys, entry codes etc.).
•	Staff working in secure areas must challenge anyone not wearing a badge. Visitors
to secure areas are required to sign in and out with arrival and departure times and
are required to wear an identification badge.
•	An employee/seafarer escorts all visitors accessing secure areas at all times.
•	Keys to all secure areas housing IT/OT equipment and lockable ICT cabinets are
held centrally by the appropriate personnel onboard and ashore.
•	Where breaches do occur, or an employee/seafarer leaves outside normal
termination circumstances, all identification and access tools/passes (e.g., badges,
keys etc.) are recovered.

sections.name: 20.13.2 Working in Secure Areas
sections.content:
For all employees, third parties and other stakeholders who are given access to a secure area
the following procedural instructions will apply.
Ashore & Onboard
•	Ensure you understand the specific instructions for all secure areas to which you are
granted access.
•	DO NOT tell anyone about the secure area if you are requested not to.
•	Inform security of visitors you are expecting in time and escort them at all times.
•	DO NOT keep secure doors open for longer than necessary. NEVER allow anyone
to tail-gate behind you through a secure entry point.
•	DO NOT work in the secure area on your own unless by prior arrangement.
•	NEVER lend anyone your ID badge or expose it to possible theft or loss. Challenge
and/or report anyone not wearing an ID badge and remain vigilant whilst within the
secure area.
•	DO NOT tell anyone your access PIN code or write your PIN code down.
•	Check vacant areas for signs of unauthorized access. Always ensure that doors and
windows are secure before leaving if you are the last one out of the secure area.
•	The use of photographic, video or audio recording equipment is prohibited within the
secure area unless by prior arrangement with the CSO / SSO.
•	DO NOT leave classified information unattended in clear view of visitors.

sections.name: 20.13.3 Clear Desk & Clear Screen Policy
sections.content:
A Clear Desk & Screen Policy is a tool to ensure that all sensitive/confidential materials are
removed from an end user workspace and locked away when the items are not in use or an
employee leaves his workstation.
It is one of the top strategies to utilize when trying to reduce the risk of security breaches in
the workplace. Such a policy can also increase employee’s awareness about protecting
sensitive information.
Clear Desk Policy:
•	Where practically possible, store paper and computer media in suitable locked safes,
cabinets or other forms of security furniture when not in use, especially outside
working hours.
•	Where lockable safes, filing cabinets, drawers, cupboards etc. are not available, lock
office doors if left unattended.
•	Store hard copy documents containing any personal data, or confidential, restricted
or sensitive information only if necessary.
•	Secure all confidential, restricted or sensitive information in hardcopy or electronic
form at the end of the day and when you are away from your desk for an extended
period.
•	Remove any confidential, restricted or sensitive information from desks and lock them
in a drawer when a desk is left unoccupied at any time.
•	Immediately clear from printers any confidential, restricted or sensitive information,
when printed. Where possible, use printers with a ‘locked job’ facility.
•	Lock office areas when they are not in use and it is safe to do so.
•	Store any visit, appointment or message books in a locked area when not in use.
•	DO NOT keep any personally identifiable information on desks within reach or sight
of visitors.
•	Store keys for desk drawers, cabinets and other secure areas in the dedicated key
safe.
•	Remove any restricted or sensitive information from the desk and lock in a drawer
when the desk is unoccupied and at the end of business day.
•	Immediately remove from the printer printouts containing classified information.
•	Use paper shredder equipment to destroy classified printouts.
Clear Screen Policy:
•	DO NOT leave computer terminals logged on when unattended.
•	Ensure computer terminals are password protected.
•	Ensure that computer screens are angled away from the view of unauthorized
persons.
•	Log off computer workstations at the end of the working day, to allow security updates
to be installed during the evening.
•	Set the Windows Security Lock to activate when there is no activity for a short pre-
determined period of time.
•	Ensure that the Windows Security Lock is password protected for reactivation.
•	DO NOT leave passwords on sticky notes posted on or under a computer. DO NOT
leave them written down or in an accessible location.
•	Log off or lock your machines (by pressing the Windows key and L) when you leave
the room.
•	Erase whiteboards containing restricted and/or sensitive information.
•	Lock away any portable computing devices such as unused laptops, digital cameras
and tablets in a drawer or the server room.
•	Mass storage devices such as CDROM, DVD or USB drives are sensitive data. Ensure
they are locked away in a drawer or the server room.

sections.name: 20.13.4 Equipment Security
sections.content:
Ensure the following:
•	All general computer equipment is located in suitable physical locations that:
	o	Limit the risks from environmental hazards, e.g., heat, fire, smoke, water,
dust and vibration.
	o	Limit the risk of theft e.g., if necessary, items such as laptops are physically
attached to the desk.
	o	Allow workstations handling sensitive data to be positioned so as to
eliminate the risk of the data being seen by unauthorized people.
•	Data are stored on network file servers where available. This ensures that information
lost, stolen or damaged via unauthorized access can be restored and its integrity
maintained.
•	All servers located outside of the data center are sited in a physically secure
environment.
•	Business critical systems are protected by an Un-interruptible Power Supply (UPS)
to reduce the operating system and data corruption risk from power failures.
•	All items of equipment are recorded in the IT/OT asset inventory. Procedures are in
place to ensure the inventory is updated as soon as assets are received or disposed
of.

sections.name: 20.14 Management of Change Process
sections.content:
The objective of this process is to ensure that changes to IT/OT services and their associated
components are recorded and then evaluated, authorized, prioritized, planned, tested,
implemented, documented and reviewed in a controlled manner.
A change request:
•	May arise for many reasons, including the following:
	o	An IT/OT incident or problem
	o	New hardware installation
	o	New functionality
	o	IT/OT Infrastructure upgrades
	o	New or changed legislation
	o	Retirement of service.
•	Must be assessed for impact (including information security implications) and
resource requirements before being considered by the DPA. To assist with impact
assessment, the identification of related systems/components affected by the
proposed change and also input from other affected support groups may be required.
•	After assessment, if the change is deemed acceptable, it will be authorised by the
DPA.
•	Once implemented, it will be reviewed and, subject to the findings of the review,
closed.
The Company:
•	Retains an authorization process according to UMMS Chapter 13 for IT/OT and
communication systems that does not allow any unexpected, unattended, or
unauthorized changes to critical systems or in operational systems that connect to
critical systems.
•	Performs a formal, rigorous change-control process critical to documenting IT/OT
systems, maintaining knowledge of both, and implementing cybersecurity controls.
•	Maintains logs, system diagrams, and records for all business-critical or mission-
critical systems that note the changes made during the change-control process.
•	When applicable, implements the parallel run model, which is a type of new system
deployment testing where the new system and the old one are run in parallel. Each
major or significant user/system process is performed on each system simultaneously
to ensure that the new system supports all required business functionality that the old
system supported or provided.

sections.name: 20.15.1 Types of Malware
sections.content:
Malware comes in many forms and is constantly changing as previous attack routes are closed
and new ones are found. The most common types of malware found today are:
•	Macro viruses infect applications such as Microsoft Word or Excel.
•	File infectors	usually attach themselves to executable code, such as .exe files. Another
version of a file infector associates itself with a file by creating a virus file with
the same name, but an .exe extension. Therefore, when the file is opened, the virus
code will execute.
•	System or boot-record infectors: A boot-record virus attaches to the master boot
record on hard disks. When the system is started, it will look at the boot sector and
load the virus into memory, where it can propagate to other disks and computers.
•	Polymorphic viruses	conceal themselves through varying cycles of encryption and
decryption.
•	Stealth viruses take over system functions to conceal themselves.
•	Trojans	is a program that hides in a useful program and usually has a malicious
function. A major difference between viruses and Trojans is that Trojans do not self-
replicate.
•	Logic bombs	is a type of malicious software that is appended to an application and
is triggered by a specific occurrence, such as a logical condition or a specific date
and time.
•	Worms differ from viruses in that they do not attach to a host file, but are self-
contained programs that propagate across networks and computers.
•	Droppers	is a program used to install viruses on computers.
•	Ransomware is a form of malware designed to encrypt files on a device, rendering
any files and the systems that rely on them unusable.
Often these types of malware are used in combination with each other.

sections.name: 20.15.2.1 Phishing
sections.content:
This method involves tricking the user into taking some action that causes a malicious program
to run and infect the computer being used. It is usually achieved via the blanket sending of
unsolicited emails (Spam) with file attachments or web links included in them. When the user
opens the file or clicks on the link the malicious action is triggered.
Phishing attacks can be very believable and enticing to the user. More targeted versions of
phishing have appeared such as Spear Phishing (aimed at a particular organization) and even
Whaling (aimed at an individual).

sections.name: 20.15.2.2 Websites and Mobile Code
sections.content:
The widespread use of mobile code such as JavaScript on websites has provided attackers
with another route to infect computers with malware. Often websites will be created to host
the malware which is activated either upon clicking on a link or in some cases simply by visiting
the website.
Increasingly, legitimate websites are being compromised and made to host malware without
the owner’s knowledge, making this type of attack very difficult for the user to avoid.

sections.name: 20.15.2.3 Removable Media
sections.content:
USB memory sticks, CDs, DVDs and other removable media devices provide an effective way
of spreading malware onto additional computers. When the media is inserted into the machine
the malware will either run and infect the target or will copy itself onto the removable media in
order to prepare to infect the next machine it is plugged into.

sections.name: 20.15.2.4 Hacking
sections.content:
Hacking or “Cracking”, is a more targeted and therefore less common method of introducing
malware onto a computer or network by gaining unauthorised access to the network from
outside (and sometimes inside) the organization.
This method requires more knowledge on the part of the perpetrator and often exploits existing
vulnerabilities in the software or network devices being used. Once access has been gained,
malware will be installed remotely onto the compromised machine.

sections.name: 20.15.3 Anti - Malware Controls
sections.content:
The key concept adopted in this policy is “defence in depth” and no single control must be
relied upon to provide adequate protection. This is a list of necessary controls, all of which are
implemented where possible to guard against the threats outlined in the previous section.

sections.name: 20.15.3.1 Firewall
sections.content:
The Company installs a firewall(s) system at all points at which:
•	The internal ashore network is connected to the Internet.
•	The internal onboard network is connected to the Internet.
•	The Company’s office network is connected with the ship’s network.

sections.name: 20.15.3.2 Anti-Virus / Endpoint Protection
sections.content:
The Company:
•	Safeguards endpoints or entry points of end-user devices such as desktops, laptops, and mobile devices from being exploited by malicious actors and campaigns.
•	Protects the endpoints from malware spreading via removable media.
•	Identifies and prevents cyberattacks from sophisticated malware and evolving zero-
day threats.
•	Controls and monitors external removable devices (i.e., USB’s, external hard disks).
•	Uses anti-virus software, (SentinelOne) ashore and onboard at key locations:
	o	Email servers
	o	Proxy servers
	o	All other servers (i.e., Domain Name System (DNS), Web, Active Directory)
	o	All user computers
	o	Mobile devices, including laptops, (phones and tablets where possible).
•	Ensures that:
	o	Anti-virus clients are set to obtain signature updates on a regular basis.
	o	Regular full scans are set to provide real time protection.
	o	Users can not disable the Antivirus protection.
	o	Email communication is replicated i.e., GTMail replicated server.
	o	Antivirus updates are distributed by the shore-side (or cloud where
applicable) server to all ships.
	o	Whitelist and Blacklist setup of email addresses is configured, where
applicable.
	o	Antivirus logging is enabled on all ships. If applicable, it is being replicated
to the shore-side server for review.
Malware Defense:
•Utilize centrally managed anti-malware software.
•Ensure anti-malware software signatures are updated.
•Enable operating system (OS) anti-exploitation features/deploy
anti-exploit technologies.
•Configure anti-malware scanning of removable media.
•Configure devices to not auto-run content.
CAUTION
•Centralize anti-malware logging for analysis and alerting.
•Enable DNS query logging.
•Enable command-line audit logging.

sections.name: 20.15.3.3 Email Filtering
sections.content:
The Company installs a system (physical or cloud solution) which:
•	Filters out unsolicited and potentially harmful emails (spam).
•	Blocks or removes attachments containing malware before delivery to the user.
•	Filters suspicious mail fishing links which are blocked or removed when malware is
detected.

sections.name: 20.15.3.4 Web Content Filtering
sections.content:
Web content filtering is the practice of blocking access to web content that may be deemed
offensive, inappropriate, or even dangerous.
The Company installs a hardware or software-based Content Filtering solution which:
•	Establishes rules about the types of visited internet sites.
•	Prohibits access to pornographic, drug, alcohol, gambling and other malicious sites.
•	Uses keywords or other commonalities between sites so as to group content into
categories - such as gambling and human trafficking.

sections.name: 20.15.3.5 Ransomware Protection
sections.content:
The Company takes into serious consideration ransomware threat by using where applicable,
below counter measures:
•	Maintains offline, backups of data and regularly tests the backups.
•	Maintains updated “gold images” of critical systems in case they need to be rebuilt.
•	Creates, maintains, and exercises a basic cyber incident response plan and
associated communications plan that includes response and notification procedures
for a ransomware incident.
Infection Vectors
Internet:
•	Conduct regular vulnerability scanning to identify and address vulnerabilities.
•	Regularly patch and update software and operating systems to the latest available
versions.
•	Ensure devices are properly configured and that security features are enabled.
•	Employ best practices (i.e., multifactor authentication, strong passwords) for use of
RDP and other remote desktop services.
•	Disable or block Server Message Block (SMB) protocol outbound and remove or
disable outdated versions of SMB
Phishing:
•	Implement a cybersecurity user awareness and training program that includes
guidance on how to identify and report suspicious activity or incidents.
•	Apply filters at the email gateway to filter out emails with known malicious
indicators.
•	Consider disabling macro scripts for Microsoft Office files transmitted via email.
Precursor Malware Infection:
•	Ensure antivirus and anti-malware software and signatures are up to date.
•	Use only authorized software.
•	Consider implementing an intrusion detection system (IDS) to detect command and
control activity.
Third Parties: Consider the Company’s risk management to meet its mission.

sections.name: 20.15.4 Vulnerability Management
sections.content:
The Company ashore and onboard:
•	Collects information on software vulnerabilities from vendors and third-party sources
and updates applied where available.
•	If possible, updates are applied automatically as soon as they are released.
•	Performs vulnerability scanning regularly, particularly on business-critical IT/OT
systems and networks.

sections.name: 20.15.5 Threat Monitoring and Alerts
sections.content:
Information about cyber emerging threats is obtained from various sources. Users are alerted
proactively of potential attacks, via regular training, campaigns, posters and drills.

sections.name: 20.16 User Awareness & Training
sections.content:
The personnel have a crucial role in protecting IT and OT systems ashore and onboard.
Training and awareness must match the appropriate levels for:
•	Onboard personnel, including the Master, Officers, and crew
•	Shoreside personnel, supporting the ship's management and operation.
A training program is available for all personnel, covering at least the following:
•	Risks related to:
	o	Emails and safe behavior
	o	Internet usage, including social media, chat forums, and cloud-based file
storage
	o	Use of removable media and personal devices.
•	Installing and maintaining software on the Company's hardware using infected
hardware (removable media) or software (infected package)
•	Safeguarding user information and passwords
•	Cyber risks concerning the physical presence of non-Company personnel, i.e., where
third-party technicians work on equipment without supervision
•	Detecting suspicious activity or devices and reporting procedures for a potential cyber
incident
•	Awareness of the consequences or impact of cyber incidents on the ship's safety and
operations
•	Understanding the implementation of preventative maintenance routines, such as
antivirus and antimalware, patching, backups, and incident response planning and
testing
•	Protection procedures against risks from service providers' removable media before
connecting to the ship's systems
•	Cybersecurity related International regulatory and Industry references.
The Company promotes cybersecurity awareness to all staff by various actions, i.e.:
•	Onboard presentation and discussion with crew during ICT attendances.
•	Cybersecurity training records are being kept whenever training takes place.
•	Discussion with on-signers during briefing procedures.
•	Notifications, bulletins, and instruction emails that are systematically being sent by
the IT Department to the ships and to the office users.
•	Posters promoting Cybersecurity.

sections.name: 20.17 IT / OT Software & Hardware Management
sections.content:
This procedure sets out how hardware and software of IT/OT and Communication systems
ashore and onboard will be acquired, tested, installed and supported within the Company.

sections.name: 20.17.1 Purchasing
sections.content:
IT Department:
•	Follow corporate general purchasing procedures.
•	Ensure equipment compliance with safety and cybersecurity regulations.
•	Ensure supplier provides licenses, download links or installation disks, and
instructions.
OT software comes with the equipment it monitors and controls, so there is no need for formal
acquisition requests and approvals.

sections.name: 20.17.2 Testing
sections.content:
•	Before deploying any software or hardware, the IT Department ensures that its
operation does not affect the existing systems' and services' integrity.
•	Test, using demo licenses, all new IT and OT software or software upgrades for
correct operation and compatibility with current infrastructure.

sections.name: 20.17.3 Installation
sections.content:
•	Any new installation is permitted only with the approval and supervision of the IT
team and if needed by the appropriate Manager. Licensed software will be installed
by the IT Department or appropriate technical team of a contractor or supplier upon
request with special caution on OT systems.
•	The user is not allowed to install any hardware of IT/OT system.
•	The user is not allowed to install any software that is licensed to them personally, whether or not it is free, shareware or commercial:
	o	If a user tries to install a new program, a pop-up window appears on the
screen requesting administrator credentials.
	o	Only the IT Manager has these credentials.
The Company has removed all administrative privileges from all users through its main
Administrative Control.

sections.name: 20.17.4 Maintenance
sections.content:
Maintenance during the system's lifecycle is necessary to maximize operating efficiency and
minimize security issues. For all the IT/OT assets, the Company:
•	Gets the latest applicable upgrades/updates.
•	Maintains contracts with vendors or suppliers.
Software updates provide solutions for features that are not working as intended (bugs) or add
enhancements to resolve compatibility issues. They also include device driver updates.
Software upgrades refer to new versions of software that provide major/significant changes
(inclusion/removal of features) over the current version.
•	OT systems: The vendor of equipment provides information about available
updates/upgrades.
•	IT systems: Feedback is coming by email notifications directly from software
providers.
Malware Defense:
•Catalog hardware configurations, software holdings and licenses
to prioritize and apply patches.
•Test system’s application patches on a testbed before applying to
operational systems.
•Restrict software from running unless it concerns tested and
CAUTION
approved software (whitelisting).
•Document any new changes to systems.
Vendor / Contractor / Supplier Support Team:
•	Perform ICT system software upgrades or deployment.
•	Especially on ships, the installation files must get to the systems onboard.
Depending on the size of setup, the scope of installation (specific ship, whole fleet),
and the criticality of deployment, the installation files can be transferred through
media storage disks (physical transfer) or by communication links (through
satellite).
•	When the files are onboard, a member of the IT Department proceeds with the
software installation remotely or provides installation instructions to the Master.
IT Department:
•	Perform ICT system software upgrades or deployment.
•	Especially on ships, the installation files must get to the systems onboard. Depending
on the size of setup, the scope of installation (specific ship, whole fleet), and the
criticality of deployment, the installation files can be transferred through media
storage disks (physical transfer) or by communication links (through satellite).
•	When the files are onboard, a member of the IT Department proceeds with the
software installation remotely or provides installation instructions to the Master.
Master:
•	In cases where a customized setup is pre-configured by the IT Department (through
a "runasp" executable), proceed with the installation directly. In such cases, the setup
folder also includes a document (doc/pdf) with detailed step-by-step installation
instructions.
•	Following a new software deployment (or upgrade of an existing one), performance
tests define if the software performs as expected, i.e., Disk I/O, CPU/RAM utilization, network latency, monitoring possible deviations.
•	Finally, verify the product's installed version by visually checking that the application's
update/upgrade to the desired version (through the Help/About menu dialogs or the
Programs and features list, etc.) was successful.
The Company for all its IT/OT software and hardware equipment:
•	Retains all copies of manufacturer’s instructions.
•	Identifies recommended service intervals and specifications.
•	Enables a call-out process in case of failure.
•	Ensures only authorized technicians complete any work on the equipment.
•	Records details, if possible, of all remedial work carried out.
•	Records details, if possible, of faults incurred and actions required.
•	Maintains a service history record of equipment so that decisions can be made
regarding the appropriate time for it to be replaced.
•	Ensures that manufacturer’s maintenance instructions are documented and available
for support staff to use when arranging repairs.
•	If the equipment is to be passed onto another/into the Company (e.g., ship
acquisition), data removal must be achieved by using approved, appropriately secure
software tools.

sections.name: 20.17.5 Removal
sections.content:
Ensure the following:
•	Management of Change and relevant RA is prepared and submitted before
proceeding with software/hardware removal.
•	Software/Hardware removal is performed in the production environment.
•	Equipment that is to be disposed must have all of its data erased/destroyed.
•	A new revision of the ICT Software/Hardware Inventory is prepared by removing the
relevant record.
•	When a software program is no longer required, the IT Department is informed.
•	Software licenses from removed systems may be reused by the IT Department.
•	Users MUST NOT remove licensed software from corporate devices.

sections.name: 20.17.6 Backup policy
sections.content:
The purpose of this policy is to provide means to:
•	Restore the integrity of the IT/OT systems in the event of a hardware/software failure
or physical disaster.
•	Provide a measure of protection against human error or the inadvertent deletion of
important files.
Designated personnel: Ensure that the below policy is implemented:
•	All user-level and system-level information maintained by	the Company is backed up
periodically. The backup media is stored with sufficient protection and proper
environmental conditions.
•	The frequency and extent of backups are in accordance with the importance of the
information and the acceptable risk as determined by the data owner.
•	The information resources backup and recovery process for each system is
documented and periodically reviewed.
•	Any vendor(s) providing offsite (including cloud solutions) backup storage is cleared
to handle the highest level of information stored.
•	Physical access controls implemented at offsite backup storage locations meet or
exceed the physical access controls of the source systems. Additionally, backup
media are protected in accordance with the highest sensitivity level of information
stored.
•	A process is implemented to verify the success of the Company electronic information
backup.
•	Back-up copies of operating systems and other critical information system software
are not stored, whenever possible, in the same location as the operational software.
•	The system backup information is provided with protection from unauthorized
modification and environmental conditions.
•	Backups are periodically tested to ensure that they are recoverable.
•	Procedures between the Company and the offsite backup storage vendor(s) are (if
applicable) reviewed at least annually.
•	When Backup tapes are used, have at a minimum the following identifying criteria
that can be readily identified by labels and/or a bar-coding system:
a.	System name
b.	Creation Date
c.	Sensitivity
d.	Contact Information.

sections.name: 20.18 Network Security
sections.content:
This section sets out the Company’s rules and standards for network protection and
guidance.
A “Defence in Depth” approach is adopted to network security whereby multiple layers of
controls are used to ensure that the failure of a single component does not compromise the
network.
At key points in the network a “defence diversity” approach must also be taken so that
vulnerabilities are minimised.

sections.name: 20.18.1 Network Segregation
sections.content:
Where appropriate, a network will consist of a set of smaller networks segregated from each
other based on either trust levels or organizational boundaries (or both).
For a large network this may be achieved using separate domains, particularly where separate
organizations’ networks are being linked. An appropriate level of trust must be configured at
the domain level and domain perimeters must be secured using a firewall where appropriate.
Within networks, Virtual Local Area Networks (VLANs) will be used to segregate organizational
units.
Onboard best practice guide:
•	Create an IDMZ to completely separate the Business and Crew networks from all OT
networks.
•	Use data diodes as single direction gateways preventing malicious code entering the
OT network from IT compromised devices.
•	Create Business and Crew VLANs.
•	When applicable, use Visitor/Guest VLAN for third party’s access.
•	Consider using different color ethernet cabling for every VLAN.
•	Avoid putting any hosts on the default VLAN (VLAN 1).
•	Enable explicit tagging of the Native VLAN for all trunk ports.
•	Use of dedicated switch with different VLANs for OT systems, where possible.
•	Avoid Inter-VLAN routing.
•	If applicable, use Vitrual Access Control Lists (VACLs) to filter traffic within a VLAN, otherwise use extended ACLs.
In a cloud environment, ensure that requirements for segregating networks to achieve tenant
isolation are defined and the cloud service provider’s ability to meet these requirements is
verified.
Figure 1: Ship Network Architecture Diagram (BIMCO Workbook, 3rd Edition 2022)
Ashore best practice guide:
•	Create VLANs per Department.
•	Consider creating Guest VLAN for onsite or remote third party’s access.
•	Consider using different color ethernet cabling for every VLAN.
•	Avoid putting any hosts on the default VLAN (VLAN 1).
•	Enable explicit tagging of the Native VLAN for all trunk ports.
•	Where applicable, avoid Inter-VLAN routing (e.g., third parties VLAN for remote
maintenance).
•	If applicable, use VACLs to filter traffic within a VLAN, otherwise use extended
ACLs.
In a cloud environment, ensure that requirements for segregating networks to achieve tenant
isolation are defined and the cloud service provider’s ability to meet these requirements is
verified.
Securing OT Systems:
•Implement Network Segmentation – IDMZ.
•Backup all OT software.
•Harden devices by:
	o	Update-patch systems
	o	Change default passwords
	o	Restrict and review user permissions and accounts
WARNING
regularly
	o	Disable unnecessary features.
•Collect logs, where feasible via a Security Information and Event
Management System (SIEM).
•Get automatic alerts by email.

sections.name: 20.18.2 Perimeter Security & Resilience
sections.content:
At all perimeters between the internal network and an external network (such as the Internet) effective measures are in place ensuring that only authorised network traffic is permitted.
This will usually consist of at least one Stateful Inspection firewall and for major links with the Internet an Application (or Application Gateway) firewall must be used. For connections such as broadband at smaller locations, a Packet Filtering firewall may suffice, depending on the results of a RA.
Servers that are intended to be accessed from an external, insecure network (such as web servers) are located in a Demilitarised Zone (DMZ) of the firewall.
Onboard
•	Using a different satellite (such as VSAT and FBB) or 4G/5G with shore-side network
in order to provide redundancy for the data and voice communication of the ship.
•	SatCom/4G/5G network providers are configured in an Active-Active fail-safe mode.
Ashore
•	Rules have been set up on the shore side Inmarsat Service Provider firewall
equipment in order to allow only authorized data traffic to/from the ship, bound to
specific source/destination IPs and ports.
•	The email service onboard is provided by a third party. The ship’s workstations
connect via a secure channel (whitelisted IP addresses) to the servers ashore for
email exchange to take place. Apart from the email service, antivirus, anti-phishing,
Advance Threat Protection (APT) and archiving services are also being provided.
Secure Configuration Requirements for Network Devices:
•Maintain standard security configurations.
•Document traffic configuration rules.
•Use automated tools to verify standard device configuration and
detect changes.
•Install the latest stable version of any security-related updates on
all network devices.
•Manage network devices using multi-factor authentication and
CAUTION
encrypted sessions.
•Use dedicated workstations for all network administrative tasks.
•Manage network infrastructure through a dedicated network.

sections.name: 20.18.3 Public Networks
sections.content:
For information transferred over a public network such as the Internet, strong encryption via
SSL/TLS is used to ensure the confidentiality of the data transmitted.

sections.name: 20.18.4 Wi-Fi Networks
sections.content:
Ashore & Onboard
•	Secure wireless networks using WPA2/3 encryption. DO NOT use WEP and WPA.
•	Treat wireless networks as insecure even if WPA2/3 is used as the encryption method
and install a firewall between the wireless network and the main LAN.
•	Provide a separate wireless network for visitors.
•	Wireless access points are configured to not broadcast their Service Set Identifier
(SSID) and to not allow secure connection using WPS (Wi-Fi Protected Setup) via
physical access to the access point itself.
•	Always change wireless access point admin login passwords from the default.

sections.name: 20.18.5 Physical Security
sections.content:
Ashore & Onboard
•	Remote network equipment is housed in secure cabinets which is locked at all times. Only support staff has access to the key to each cabinet.
•	Backbone and centralized network equipment is in appropriate lockable cabinets or
racks in a secure server room to which only authorized support staff has access.
•	Where possible, wireless access points located in public areas are hidden from
view.
•	Lockable protective casing protects access points if located in an unprotected public
area e.g., deck area.

sections.name: 20.18.6 Network Intrusion Detection
sections.content:
•	A Network-based Intrusion Detection System (NIDS) can be installed at the network
perimeter and at all key points within the network e.g., on critical servers.
•	For critical IT/OT networks with high security requirements, consider an Intrusion
Prevention System (IPS).

sections.name: 20.18.7 Logging and Monitoring
sections.content:
•	A Syslog server is installed which gather logs from i.e. ship servers, NAS server and
Network switches.
•	Firewall logs are monitored for signs of excessive port scanning which may be a
precursor to a remote attack.
•	Where installed, a Network-based Intrusion Detection System is configured to alert
the Network Operations team.
•	Network monitoring for availability is achieved using an appropriate SNMP-based
network management tool (such as Nagios, Solar Winds or WhatsUp Gold).
•	Where installed, alerts from the Network Access Control (NAC) system are
addressed immediately.

sections.name: 20.18.8 Network Changes
sections.content:
•	All changes to network devices are subject to the MoC process.
•	Update configuration records whenever such changes are carried out.

sections.name: 20.18.9 Video Conference Policy
sections.content:
The Company uses approved Instant Messenger and Video Conferencing software tools to
fulfill its business needs. The following rules apply:
•	All usernames are unique and managed by the appointed account Administrator.
•	Personal, non-corporate accounts are strictly prohibited.
•	File transfer of confidential data is prohibited.
•	Messages transmitted through a session (i.e., Skype) are automatically encrypted
from end to end.
•	Recording of Video or VOIP calls are permitted depending on the sensitivity of the
conference.
•	Recording of presentations are allowed depending on the terms agreed for each
presentation.

sections.name: 20.18.10 Internet Acceptable Use Policy
sections.content:
The purpose of this Policy is to protect both the Company and the employee and provide
employees with rules and guidelines, mitigation measures and controls about the appropriate
use of Internet access for private, personal use contributing to social connectivity but without
compromising the	ship’s safety of navigation or operational efficiency.
Company’s employees: You must abide by the following rules:
•	You must use the internet including social media, chat forums etc., responsibly.
•	All internet data that is composed, transmitted and/or received by the Company’s
computer systems is considered to belong to the employer and to be part of the
Company’s official data. It is therefore subject to disclosure for legal reasons to
authorized third parties. This also applies to sharing or transmitting data, including
but not limited to files, photos and text information, taken offline that was acquired
from the Company’s computer systems.
•	The Company reserves the right to monitor internet traffic and access data that is
composed, sent or received through its online and local network connections.
•	Data sent, downloaded or received via the Company’s internet	system MUST NOT
contain content that is deemed to be offensive, provocative or distasteful. This
includes, but not restricted to the use of vulgar or socially unacceptable or
discriminatory language/images regarding age, race, sex, national origin, disability,
religion, culture, medical condition and sexual orientation.
•	Data sent, downloaded or received via the Company’s internet	system may be
blocked by the IT Department if deemed to contravene this Policy and/or be harmful
to the business.
•	Internet is to be used in accordance with local national laws and regulations. The
downloading of any inappropriate, illegal or offensive material is strictly prohibited.
•	You MUST NOT:
	o	Access the	internet onboard while on duty and during working hours to avoid
distractions.
	o	Send or post discriminatory, harassing or threatening messages or images
on the internet, including social media, chat forums etc.
	o	Use devices to perpetrate software, film or music piracy.
	o	Disclose someone else's personal information.
	o	Violate copyright laws, download or copy software and electronic files.
	o	Share confidential material, photos of work areas, trade secrets, or
proprietary information relating to the Company.
	o	Hijack devices or hack into accounts.
	o	Send or post information that is defamatory to the employer, its services,
employees and/or customers/contractors.
	o	Post or exchange confidential Company’s information and/or disclose
corporate information that is not public.
	o	Introduce malicious software onto the Company’s computer network and/or
jeopardize the security of the Company’s electronic communications
systems.
	o	Write, copy, execute or attempt to introduce any computer code designed to
replicate, damage or otherwise hinder the performance of or access to any
of the Company’s computers, networks or data.
	o	Send or post chain letters, solicitations or advertisements not authorized by
the Company.
	o	Communicate personal views as representing those of the Company.
	o	Abuse, exploit or damage any internet or local network connected devices.
	o	Conduct fraudulent or illegal activities, including but not limited to
gambling, trafficking in drugs or weapons or participating in terrorist
propaganda or acts.
	o	Perform any act that may defame, abuse, embarrass, tarnish or portray a
negative image of the Company, employees, or any other party related to the
Company.
•	If unsure about what constitutes acceptable internet usage, ask the Company for
further guidance and clarification.

sections.name: 20.18.11 Use of Email Service
sections.content:
This section defines the rules and guidelines for the proper and secure use of corporate email
which must be used only for business purposes.
Ashore:
•	Company email accounts are business records and must be used only for Company’s
business-related purposes. Personal communication is permitted on a limited
basis.
•	The email system allows sending and receiving emails up to a specific size (i.e. 25
MB.
•	In principle, the Company does not have access to email communications which are
conducted through business email accounts. As an exception, the Company may
monitor email communications when this is absolutely necessary for the protection of
its overriding legitimate interests, always in accordance with the GDPR. Such
legitimate interests may include the protection of the Company's interests, the health
and safety of its personnel, the prevention and investigation of criminal activities or
breaches of the users’ obligations arising from the employment.
Onboard:
•	Ship’s email to be used only for Company’s business-related purposes. Personal
communication is not permitted.
•	It is prohibited to forward ship’s emails to personal (non-Company) email accounts
or to store in personal devices.
•	Email communications sent through the ship’s email accounts may be monitored
when this is absolutely necessary for the protection of the Company’s overriding
legitimate interests, always in accordance with the GDPR. Such legitimate interests
may include the protection of the Company's interests, the health and safety of its
crew, the prevention and investigation of criminal activities or breaches.
•	The email system allows sending and receiving emails up to a specific size (i.e. 3
MB.
•	Ship’s email hosted or not in Company’s premises is protected from viruses and spam
emails from central tools installed at onshore premises or cloud service providers.
All personnel ashore & onboard:
•	DO NOT use auto-forwarding on emails e.g., whilst on holiday, if there is a possibility
that this may result in classified information sharing.
•	Manage your email account(s) to remain within the mailbox size limit (i.e. 40MB)
•	If you need to send a larger email for legitimate business purposes then contact the
IT Department for advice.
•	Where possible, make use of links to files within email messages rather than
attaching a copy of the file.
•	Ensure the system has configured user accounts.
•	Email zipped or encrypted files.
•	You MUST NOT:
	o	Transmit by email any file attachments which you know to be infected with a
virus.
	o	Use third party email systems, such as Google, Yahoo, etc. to conduct
Company business, to create any binding transactions, or to store and retain
emails on behalf of the Company.
	o	Download data or programs of any nature from unknown sources.
	o	Disable or reconfigure the installed anti-virus system operating on a
computer used to access email facilities.
	o	Forward virus warnings other than to the IT Department.
•	All e-mails sent from the Company addresses to recipients outside will automatically
carry, when possible, a disclaimer.

sections.name: 20.19.1 Cyber incident & Contact Details
sections.content:
A loss of IT systems, including a data breach of confidential information, would be a business
continuity issue and would normally not have immediate, significant impact on the safe
operation of the ship.
The loss of OT systems may have a significant and immediate impact
on the safe operation of the ship.
CAUTION
Should a cyber incident result in the loss or malfunctioning of OT systems, take actions to
guarantee the immediate safety of crew, ship, cargo and the protection of the environment.
In the event of a cyber incident (in IT or OT systems) notify the Company and immediately
implement the response and recovery plans, as described in the following sections.
CONTACT DETAILS FOR CYBERSECURITY INCIDENTS

sections.name: 20.19.2 Detecting and reporting a cyber incident
sections.content:
The use of monitoring and reporting systems, where possible, help identify ongoing threats.
Other methods of detecting a cyber incident include:
IT Systems:
•	Unusual password activity, e.g., an unexpected prompt to change a password
•	Suspicious pop-ups or adware, especially when browsing the Internet
•	Unexpectedly slow or unresponsive systems or network
•	Clear evidence of a virus or system breach, e.g., a demand for ransomware payment, detection of a physical device, such as a key logger
•	Email/Communication failure
•	Ship Server breakdown.
•Report cyber security incidents on IT systems, actual or
suspected, to IT Department and the CySSO immediately.
Provide as much information and details as possible. Include
screenshots, if possible.
•Master: For ship communication issues you may contact the
communication vendor directly. Include IT Department in any
email communication.
CAUTION
OT Systems:
•	The engine slow down unexpectedly (especially on a risk area)
•	The bridge team have concluded that the navigation systems are no longer
trustworthy or loss of availability of electronic navigational equipment
•	Unexpectedly slow or unresponsive systems or network
•	Loss of essential connectivity with the shore, including but not limited to the
availability of GMDSS communications
•	Loss of availability of industrial control systems, including propulsion, auxiliary
systems and other critical systems, as well as loss of integrity of data management
and control
•	Unauthorized access to critical systems
•	Unauthorized connection of removable media or personal devices.
Report actual or suspected cyber security incidents on OT systems to
the Technical S/T and the CySCO immediately. Provide as much
information/details as possible. Include screenshots, if possible.
CAUTION
In case of cyber security incidents on OT critical systems, notify the
Company’s ERT, in order for the ERP to get started.
WARNING

sections.name: 20.19.3 Prioritizing cyber incidents
sections.content:
Cyber incidents are not handled on a first-come, first-served basis as a result of resource
limitations. Instead, they are prioritized based on the relevant factors, such as the following:
Functional impact of the Incident: Incidents targeting Company’s systems typically impact
the business functionality that those systems provide, resulting in some type of negative
impact to their users.
Category
Definition
Low
Minimal, if any effect. The Company can still provide all critical services to
all users but has lost efficiency.
Medium
The Company has lost the ability to provide a critical service to a subset of
system users.
High
The Company is no longer able to provide some critical services to any
users.
Critical
Several critical systems have been compromised and are inoperable.
Information impact of the Incident: Incidents may affect the confidentiality, integrity, and
availability of the Company’s information. Incident handlers must consider how this information
extraction will impact the Company’s overall mission.
Category
Definition
No impact
No information was extracted, changed, deleted, or otherwise
compromised.
Privacy Breach
Sensitive personally identifiable information (PII) of employees,
beneficiaries, etc. was accessed or extracted.
Proprietary
Unclassified proprietary information, such as protected critical
infrastructure information (PCII), was accessed or extracted.
Breach
Integrity and/or
Sensitive or proprietary information was changed or deleted and/or
Confidential information released to external parties.
Confidentiality
Loss
Recoverability from the Incident: The size of the incident and impact will determine the
amount of time and resources that must be spent on recovering from such incident.
Category
Definition
No effort
No recoverability effort needed
Regular
Time to recovery is predictable with existing resources
Supplemented
Time to recovery is predictable with additional resources
Extended
Time to recovery is unpredictable or even not possible, additional
resources and outside help are required
Combining the functional impact to the Company’s systems and the impact to the Company’s
information determines the business impact of the incident.
The recoverability determines the possible responses that the team may take when handling
an incident. The team must prioritize the response to each incident based on its estimate of
the business impact caused and the estimated efforts required to recover from it.
In Chapter 9, Appendix I, the Cybersecurity Incident Categorization Matrix combines
the impact, recoverability, notification and further actions within an indicative timeframe.

sections.name: 20.19.4 Incident Response Plan
sections.content:
In case of cyber incidents on OT critical systems, notify the Company’s
Emergency Response Team (ERT), in order for the Emergency
Response Plan to get started.
WARNING
Effective incident response is crucial during a cyber incident. The goal is to minimize impact
and return systems to normal working order as soon as possible.
Responding to a cyber incident may however be beyond the competencies held within the
Company and onboard the ships. In such cases, external expert assistance is required to
ensure an effective response.
The following is a non-exhaustive list of the actions in response to the type of cyber incidents,
which should be addressed in contingency plans onboard:
•	Loss of availability of electronic navigational equipment or loss of integrity of
navigation related data
•	Loss of availability or integrity of external data sources, including but not limited to
GNSS
•	Loss of essential connectivity with the shore, including but not limited to the
availability of Global Maritime Distress and Safety System (GMDSS)
communications
•	Loss of availability of industrial control systems, including propulsion, auxiliary
systems and other critical systems, as well as loss of integrity of data management
and control
•	The event of a ransomware or denial or service incident.
There are 4 phases to an incident response:
Phase 1: Preparation
The Preparation phase covers the work the Company does to get ready for incident response,
including establishing the right tools and resources and training the team.
To prepare for incidents:
•	Compile a list of IT/OT assets such as networks, servers and endpoints.
•	Identify their importance and which ones are critical or hold sensitive data.
•	Set up monitoring such as:
	o	User activity
	o	Network traffic
	o	Installed software.
•	Determine which types of security events should be investigated.
•	Create detailed response steps for common types of incidents.
Phase 2: Detection and Analysis
Detection involves collecting data from IT/OT systems, security tools, publicly available
information and people inside and outside the organization, and identifying precursors (signs
that an incident may happen in the future) and indicators (data showing that an attack has
happened or is happening now).
Analysis involves identifying a baseline of normal activity for the affected systems, correlating
related events and seeing if and how they deviate from normal behavior.
Ascertain the following information:
•	How the incident occurred?
•	Which IT and/or OT systems were affected and how?
•	The extent to which the commercial and/or operational data is affected.
•	To what extend any threat to IT and OT systems remains?
Phase 3: Containment, Eradication and Recovery
Containing the outbreak of an incident is a time-critical exercise. The main goal of containment
and eradication is the prompt limitation of the impact/damage and the prevention of any further
damage to the same or other constituent systems. This includes the following steps:
•	Where possible, remove the system from the network. If it is not possible, then isolate
the infected system from its network and ensure that boundary controls are
operational between networks.
•	Check the firewall rules have not changed. Where systems are internet/VSAT facing, shut down remote access ports.
•	Ensure that anti-virus and anti-malware definitions are up to date.
•	Take a full disk/RAM image of any infected system for forensic investigation.
The purpose of recovery is to bring all affected systems back in normal operation.
IT, OT Systems and data are cleaned, recovered and restored to an operational condition.
New PCs or equipment must be purchased if the incident is severe enough to necessitate this.
Recovery plans for each system are covered in the next section.
Phase 4: Post Incident Activity
This phase helps to evaluate the reason of the incident outbreak, the missed precursors and
new indications that must be added to the procedures for earlier detection and/or prevention:
•	Investigate the incident: To understand the causes and consequences of a cyber
incident, the Company must undertake an investigation by completing the form NCR
003 “Incident Investigation Report” from Chapter 9 to report the cybersecurity
incident. If the ship’s Flag has a specific form for cyber incident reporting, it must also
be used supplementary. The information from the incident investigation is significant
for preventing a potential reoccurrence.
•	Prevent re-occurrence: Taking into account the outcome of the investigation,
actions to address any inadequacies in technical and/or procedural protection,
measures are considered, in accordance with the Company procedures, for
implementation of corrective actions.
•	Lessons Learnt: An essential part of following up a cyber security incident is to
document, communicate and build on lessons learnt. This is an on-going process in
order to learn from previous mistakes, incidents and experiences.

sections.name: 20.19.5 Incident Disaster Recovery (DR) Plan
sections.content:
The Company:
•	Defines the requirements for business continuity in the face of cyber threats.
•	Identifies risk conditions and plans against those risks so that business can continue
even in case of serious interferences.
•	Plans and provides resources for disaster recovery to ensure business continuity or
mission capabilities when responding to risk conditions.
•	Confirms that security architecture protecting its systems, facilities, personnel, and
assets has adequate replication in terms of functions during a disaster recovery
scenario.
Under no circumstance must a DR effort leave cybersecurity
unmonitored.
CAUTION
Mission-critical functions are part of asset management. As such, the Company has plans in
place to recover from these events. These plans might materialize by physical relocation,
alternate equipment, alternative work regimes, or a combination of all.
Ashore & Onboard
•	Keep recovery plans for IT/OT servers, critical applications such as ECDIS and
network equipment accessible to Officers onboard according to their responsibilities
in the plans. The Officers and potential external IT personnel must understand this
plan's purpose and scope.
•	Keep essential information and software backup facilities available to ensure
recovery after a cyber incident.
•	Recovery of essential system functions related to the ship's safe operation may
require ashore or third parties’ support assistance according to SLA’s services.
Recovery Onboard
For a detailed recovery action plan regarding:
•	Email service disruption
•	Malware/Ransomware incident
•	Loss of
	o	Satellite connectivity
	o	OT systems
	o	Electronic navigation equipment
	o	Network - Communication systems,
refer to Chapter 8 Appendix VIII.
Recovery Ashore
For a detailed recovery action plan regarding:
•	Email service disruption
•	Malware/ransomware incident
•	Loss of
	o	Internet access
	o	Network - Communication systems,
refer to Chapter 22.3.6.8 - Cyber Threat.

Functional impact of the Incident: Incidents targeting Company’s systems typically impact

impact to their users.

Definition

      "content": "In case of cyber incidents on OT critical systems, notify the Company’s

WARNING
Effective incident response is crucial during a cyber incident. The goal is to minimize impact
and return systems to normal working order as soon as possible.
Responding to a cyber incident may however be beyond the competencies held within the
Company and onboard the ships. In such cases, external expert assistance is required to
ensure an effective response.
The following is a non-exhaustive list of the actions in response to the type of cyber incidents,
which should be addressed in contingency plans onboard:
•	Loss of availability of electronic navigational equipment or loss of integrity of
navigation related data
•	Loss of availability or integrity of external data sources, including but not limited to
GNSS
•	Loss of essential connectivity with the shore, including but not limited to the
availability of Global Maritime Distress and Safety System (GMDSS)
communications
•	Loss of availability of industrial control systems, including propulsion, auxiliary
systems and other critical systems, as well as loss of integrity of data management
and control
•	The event of a ransomware or denial or service incident.
There are 4 phases to an incident response:
Phase 1: Preparation
The Preparation phase covers the work the Company does to get ready for incident response,
including establishing the right tools and resources and training the team.
To prepare for incidents:
•	Compile a list of IT/OT assets such as networks, servers and endpoints.
•	Identify their importance and which ones are critical or hold sensitive data.
•	Set up monitoring such as:
	o	User activity
	o	Network traffic
	o	Installed software.
•	Determine which types of security events should be investigated.
•	Create detailed response steps for common types of incidents.
Phase 2: Detection and Analysis
Detection involves collecting data from IT/OT systems, security tools, publicly available
information and people inside and outside the organization, and identifying precursors (signs
that an incident may happen in the future) and indicators (data showing that an attack has
happened or is happening now).
Analysis involves identifying a baseline of normal activity for the affected systems, correlating
related events and seeing if and how they deviate from normal behavior.
Ascertain the following information:
•	How the incident occurred?
•	Which IT and/or OT systems were affected and how?
•	The extent to which the commercial and/or operational data is affected.
•	To what extend any threat to IT and OT systems remains?
Phase 3: Containment, Eradication and Recovery
Containing the outbreak of an incident is a time-critical exercise. The main goal of containment
and eradication is the prompt limitation of the impact/damage and the prevention of any further
damage to the same or other constituent systems. This includes the following steps:
•	Where possible, remove the system from the network. If it is not possible, then isolate
the infected system from its network and ensure that boundary controls are
operational between networks.
•	Check the firewall rules have not changed. Where systems are internet/VSAT facing, shut down remote access ports.
•	Ensure that anti-virus and anti-malware definitions are up to date.
•	Take a full disk/RAM image of any infected system for forensic investigation.
The purpose of recovery is to bring all affected systems back in normal operation.
IT, OT Systems and data are cleaned, recovered and restored to an operational condition.
New PCs or equipment must be purchased if the incident is severe enough to necessitate this.
Recovery plans for each system are covered in the next section.
Phase 4: Post Incident Activity
This phase helps to evaluate the reason of the incident outbreak, the missed precursors and
new indications that must be added to the procedures for earlier detection and/or prevention:
•	Investigate the incident: To understand the causes and consequences of a cyber
incident, the Company must undertake an investigation by completing the form NCR
003 “Incident Investigation Report” from Chapter 9 to report the cybersecurity
incident. If the ship’s Flag has a specific form for cyber incident reporting, it must also
be used supplementary. The information from the incident investigation is significant
for preventing a potential reoccurrence.
•	Prevent re-occurrence: Taking into account the outcome of the investigation,
actions to address any inadequacies in technical and/or procedural protection,
measures are considered, in accordance with the Company procedures, for
implementation of corrective actions.
•	Lessons Learnt: An essential part of following up a cyber security incident is to
document, communicate and build on lessons learnt. This is an on-going process in
order to learn from previous mistakes, incidents and experiences."

Under no circumstance must a DR effort leave cybersecurity
unmonitored.
CAUTION

place to recover from these events. These plans might materialize by physical relocation,
alternate equipment, alternative work regimes, or a combination of all.
Ashore & Onboard
•	Keep recovery plans for IT/OT servers, critical applications such as ECDIS and
network equipment accessible to Officers onboard according to their responsibilities
in the plans. The Officers and potential external IT personnel must understand this
plan's purpose and scope.
